Cornwall's economy was fully integrated into England's,{{harvnb|Hechter|1999|p=64}}. and [[mining in Cornwall]], always an important source of employment and stability of the Cornish, experienced a process of industrialisation resulting in 30 per cent of Cornwall's adult population being employed by its mines. During this period, efforts were made by Cornish engineers to design [[steam engine]]s with which to power water pumps for Cornish mines thus aiding the extraction of mineral ore.{{harvnb|Hodge|1973|p=12}}. Industrial scale tin and copper mining operations in Cornwall melded Cornish identity with engines and heavy industry,{{harvnb|MacLeod|2007|p=343}}. and Cornwall's leading [[mining engineer]], [[Richard Trevithick]], became "as much a part of Cornwall's heritage as any legendary giant from its Celtic past".{{harvnb|MacLeod|2007|p=345}}. Trevithick's most significant success was a high-pressure steam engine used to pump water and refuse from mines, but he was also the builder of the first full-scale working railway [[steam locomotive]].{{citation |url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/trevithic_loco/ |work=[[National Museum Wales]] |accessdate=1 September 2009 |title=Richard Trevithick's steam locomotive |date=15 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110415125004/http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/trevithic_loco |archivedate=15 April 2011 |df=dmy-all }} On 21 February 1804, the world's first locomotive-hauled railway journey took place as Trevithick's unnamed steam locomotive hauled a train along the [[Rail transport|tramway]] of the [[Penydarren]] ironworks, near [[Merthyr Tydfil]] in Wales. The construction of the [[Great Western Railway]] during the [[Victorian era]] allowed for an influx of tourists to Cornwall from across Great Britain. Well into the [[Edwardian era]] and [[interwar period]], Cornwall was branded as a rural retreat, a "primitive land of magic and romance", and as an "earlier incarnation of Englishness, a place more English than an England ravaged by modernity".{{harvnb|Cubitt|1998|pp=164–166}}. Cornwall, the United Kingdom's only region with a [[Subtropics|subtropical-like climate]], became a centre for [[Tourism in England|English tourism]], its coastline dominated by [[resort town]]s increasingly composed of [[bungalow]]s and [[villa]]s. Tourists visiting Cornwall are called ''emmets'' by locals, a Cornish language word for insects, referring to the creatures that the visitors resemble when swarming Cornwall's resorts. [[John Nichols Thom]], or Mad Tom, (1799 – 31 May 1838) was a Cornishman self-declared messiah who, in the 19th century led the last battle to be fought on English soil, known as the [[Battle of Bossenden Wood]]. While not akin to the Cornish rebellions of the past, he did attract some Cornish support as well as mostly Kentish labourers, although his support was primarily of religious followers. In the latter half of the 19th century Cornwall experienced rapid deindustrialisation, with the closure of mines in particular considered by the Cornish to be both an economic and cultural disaster. This, coupled with the rise of [[Romantic nationalism]] in Europe inspired and influenced a [[Celtic Revival]] in Cornwall, a social, linguistic and artistic movement interested in Cornish medieval [[ethnology]]. This Revivalist upsurge investigated Cornwall's pre-industrial culture, using the Cornish language as the "principal badge of [Cornish] nationality and ethnic kinship”. The first effective revival of Cornish began in 1904 when [[Henry Jenner]], a Celtic language enthusiast, published his book ''Handbook of the Cornish Language''. His [[orthography]], [[Unified Cornish]], was based on Cornish as it was spoken in the 18th century, although his pupil [[Robert Morton Nance]] later steered the revival more towards the [[Middle Cornish]] that had been used in the 16th century, before the language became influenced by English. The [[visit of King George IV to Scotland]] in 1822 reinvigorated [[Scottish national identity]], melding it with romanticist notions of [[tartan]], [[kilt]]s and the [[Scottish Highlands]].{{harvnb|Pittaway|2003|p=181}}. As [[Pan-Celticism]] gathered pace in the early 20th century, Cornishman [[L. C. R. Duncombe-Jewell]] and the Cowethas Kelto-Kernuak (a Cornish language interest group) asserted the use of [[Cornish kilts and tartans]] as a "national dress ... common to all Celtic countries".{{harvnb|Ellis|1974|p=151}}. In 1924 the [[Federation of Old Cornwall Societies]] was formed to facilitate, preserve and maintain Celticity in Cornwall,{{harvnb|Ellis|1974|p=168}}. followed by the similar [[Gorseth Kernow]] in 1928,{{harvnb|Ellis|1974|pp=160–161}}. and the formation of the Cornish nationalist political party [[Mebyon Kernow]] in 1951. Increased interest and communication across the [[Celtic nations]] in Celtic languages and culture during the 1960s and 1970s spurred on the popularisation of the [[Cornish self-government movement]]. Since [[devolution]] in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, enthusiasts for Cornish culture have pressed for the Cornish language to be taught formally in Cornish schools, while Cornish nationalists have demanded greater political autonomy for Cornwall, for example that it be constituted as the [[countries of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom's fifth consistuent country]] with its own [[Cornish Assembly]]. == Geographic distribution == {{Main|Cornish diaspora}} [[File:Cornish miners - 1866.png|thumb|right|upright|alt=Two men wearing mining attire look at one-another in this black line drawing. Both wear dark clothing and mining helmets. The man on the right holds a long tool.|Cornish miners in the mid-19th century. A demise in [[mining in Cornwall]] prompted an exodus of Cornish miners and families resulting in a displaced [[Cornish diaspora]].]] The Cornish people are concentrated in Cornwall, but after the [[Age of Discovery]] in the early modern period were involved in the [[British colonisation of the Americas]] and other transcontinental and [[transatlantic migrations]]. Initially, the number of migrants was comparatively small, with those who left Cornwall typically settling in North America or else amongst the ports and [[plantation]]s of the [[Caribbean]]. In the first half of the 19th century, the Cornish people were leaders in [[tin]] and copper smelting, while [[mining in Cornwall]] was the people's major occupation. Increased competition from Australia, [[British Malaya]] and [[Bolivia]], coupled with the depletion of mineral deposits brought about an economic decline for Cornish mining lasting half a century, and prompting mass [[human migration]] from Cornwall. In each decade from 1861 to 1901, "around 20% of the Cornish male population migrated abroad"—three times that of the average of [[England and Wales]]—and totalling over a quarter of a million people lost to emigration between 1841 and 1901. There was a displacement of skilled Cornish engineers, farmers, merchants, miners and tradesmen, but their commercial and occupational expertise, particularly in [[Underground mining (hard rock)|hard rock mining]], was highly valued by the communities they met. Within Great Britain, Cornish families were attracted from Cornwall to [[North East England]]—particularly on [[Teesside]]—to partake in coal mining as a means to earn wealth by using their mining skill. This has resulted in a concentration of Cornish names on and around Teesside that persists into the 21st century.{{citation |url=http://www.newstatesman.com/life-and-society/2007/01/cornish-names-british-family |work=[[New Statesman]] |title=Britain's moving story |last=McKie |first=Robin |date=15 January 2007 |accessdate=28 August 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090710080720/http://www.newstatesman.com/life-and-society/2007/01/cornish-names-british-family |archivedate=10 July 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Large numbers of the 19th century Cornish emigrants eventually returned to Cornwall, whilst the rate of emigration from Cornwall declined after World War I.{{harvnb|Thrift|Williams|1987|p=143}}. However, the global connections of the remaining [[Cornish diaspora]], which is concentrated in [[English-speaking countries]] such as Australia, Canada, South Africa and the United States, are "very strong".{{citation |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/immig_emig/england/cornwall/article_2.shtml |title=I’m alright Jack: The Cornish Diaspora |publisher=BBC |accessdate=1 July 2009 |page=2 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123134906/http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/immig_emig/england/cornwall/article_2.shtml |archivedate=23 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Their outreach has contributed to the international spread of [[Methodism]], a movement within [[Protestantism|Protestant]] Christianity that was popular with the Cornish people at the time of their mass migration.{{harvnb|Hempton|2006|pp=25–28}}. "Cousin Jacks" is a nickname for the overseas Cornish, thought to derive from the practice of Cornishmen asking if job vacancies could be filled by their cousin named Jack in Cornwall. === Australia === {{See also|Cornish Australian}} [[File:Harold Oliver zoom.png|right|200px|thumb|[[Harold Oliver (Australian footballer)|William "Harold" Oliver]] was the son of Australian Cornish immigrants who lived in the mining town of [[Waukaringa, South Australia|Waukaringa]]. Harold Oliver was a three time national champion with the [[Port Adelaide Football Club]] in 1910, 1913 and 1914.]] From the [[History of Australia (1788–1850)|beginning of Australia's colonial period]] until after the Second World War, people from the United Kingdom made up a large majority of people coming to Australia, meaning that many Australian-born people can trace their origins to Britain.{{citation |url=http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/2f762f95845417aeca25706c00834efa/af5129cb50e07099ca2570eb0082e462!OpenDocument |title=Population characteristics: Ancestry of Australia's population |work=Australian Bureau of Statistics |date=3 June 2003 |accessdate=27 May 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617214944/http://www.abs.gov.au/AUSSTATS/abs@.nsf/2f762f95845417aeca25706c00834efa/af5129cb50e07099ca2570eb0082e462!OpenDocument |archivedate=17 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }} The Cornish people in particular were actively encouraged to emigrate to Australia following the demise of [[mining in Cornwall|Cornish mining]] in the 19th century. A "vigorous recruiting campaign" was launched to encourage the Cornish to aid with [[mining in Australia]] because of their experience and expertise.{{Harvnb|Jupp|2001|p=228}}. Free passage to South Australia in particular was granted to hundreds of Cornish miners and their families, so much so, that a large Cornish community gathered in Australia's [[Copper Coast]], and South Australia's [[Yorke Peninsula]] became known as "Little Cornwall”. It has been estimated between 1837 and 1840, 15 per cent of all assisted migrants to South Australia were Cornish. Cornish settlement impacted upon social, cultural and religious life throughout the [[history of South Australia]]. Cornish identity was embraced strongly in the Yorke Peninsula, but also in the more outlying mining towns of [[Kapunda, South Australia|Kapunda]] and [[Burra, South Australia|Burra]], where Cornish miners constituted a sizeable community.{{Harvnb|Jupp|2001|p=231}}. [[Methodism]], was the main form of religious practice for the Cornish. Methodist sensibilities were held with strong conviction by the migrant Cornish in a direct rivalry with Catholic [[Irish people]] in Australia. The [[Kernewek Lowender]] is the largest Cornish festival in the world, held in the [[Kadina, South Australia|Kadina]], [[Moonta, South Australia|Moonta]] and [[Wallaroo, South Australia|Wallaroo]] towns on the Yorke Peninsula, which attracts tens of thousands of visitors bi-annually.{{Harvnb|Jupp|2001|p=229}}. === Canada === {{See also|Cornish Canadian}} European fishing ventures in and around [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]] during the 16th century were the earliest Cornish activity in what was to become Canada. However, permanent settlement by the Cornish across the Atlantic Ocean was rare until at least the 19th century. The [[British colonisation of the Americas]] encouraged additional migration of the Cornish to [[the Canadas]], particularly by those who served in Great Britain's [[Royal Navy]]. The creation of the colony of [[British North America]] spurred more people from Cornwall to settle in North America; they were registered as English migrants. Many Cornish (and other West Country) immigrants who had been agricultural labourers settled in an area of what is now South Central Ontario in what were the counties of Northumberland, Durham and Ontario, ranging from the towns of Port Hope and Cobourg in the east, to Whitby in the west and to the north ends of those counties.Source: *''Encyclopedia of Canada's Peoples''; Paul Robert Magocsi, editor, University of Toronto Press for Multicultural History Society of Ontario, 1999 === Mexico === {{See also|White Mexican}} [[File:TowerAcostaMine.JPG|thumb|upright|right|alt=A dark angular structure viewed from its base upwards fills the scene. The sky appears light-grey and cloudy. The structure is made of a dark metal frame surmounted by platform.|A [[silver mining]] museum in [[Mineral del Monte]], a remnant of the Cornish migration to [[Mexico]] during the early-19th century.]] In 1825 a band of 60 Cornishmen left [[Falmouth, Cornwall|Falmouth]] for [[Mineral del Monte]] in central [[Mexico]] with {{convert|1500|t|lk=on}} of mining machinery with which to apply their mining skill and technologies to resuscitate Mexico's ailing [[silver mining]] industry after the neglect caused by the [[Mexican War of Independence]].{{citation |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/insideout/content/articles/2008/09/30/south_west_cornish_miners_s14_w3_feature.shtml |work=BBC News |title=The Cornish in Mexico |date=30 September 2008 |accessdate=7 September 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090204215234/http://www.bbc.co.uk/insideout/content/articles/2008/09/30/south_west_cornish_miners_s14_w3_feature.shtml |archivedate=4 February 2009 |df=dmy-all }} Following their sea voyage they attempted to dock at [[Veracruz, Veracruz|Veracruz]] but were forced away by the Spanish to a beach at Mocambo from where they hauled their machinery through jungle and swamp to [[Santa Fe, Veracruz|Santa Fe]]. During this haul through the jungle, the Cornishmen and their Mexican helpers fell victim to [[yellow fever]], resulting in 30 Cornish and 100 Mexican fatalities. The fever forced the survivors to abandon their equipment and head inland up into the mountains to Xalapa to try and escape the mosquitos for three months, until the end of the rainy season. Once the rainy season closed the Cornish and Mexican miners continued their {{convert|250|mi|km|0|adj=on}} "Great Trek" to Mineral del Monte, transporting their machinery to an altitude of {{convert|10000|ft|m|0}} above sea level and arriving at their destination on 1 May 1826. Following their arrival, the Cornish community flourished and stayed in central Mexico until the [[Mexican Revolution]] in 1910. Although the Cornish community in Mexico broadly returned to Cornwall, they left a cultural legacy; [[International Pasty Festival|Cornish pasties]], Cornish mining museums and a [[Cornish Mexican Cultural Society]] are all part of the local heritage and tradition in and around Mineral del Monte. === South Africa === {{See also|White South African}} The [[Witwatersrand Gold Rush]] of 1886 encouraged large numbers of Cornish miners to migrate to the [[South African Republic]].{{harvnb|Thrift|Williams|1987|p=142}}. Although an international gold rush, the Cornish overwhelmingly formed the skilled labour force in the [[Witwatersrand]], until the outbreak of the [[Second Boer War]] prompted a retreat. === United States === {{Main|Cornish American}} The discovery of [[lead ore]] and copper in North America prompted an influx of Cornish miners to the continent, particularly around the [[Upper Mississippi River]]. By the early 19th century Cornish people were present in the [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan]]—particularly the mining town of [[Ishpeming, Michigan|Ishpeming]].{{harvnb|Magnaghi|2008|p=1}}.{{harvnb|Magnaghi|2008|p=44}}. Additional waves of Cornish migrants followed the [[California Gold Rush]] of the mid-19th century; in the 1890s it was estimated that in [[California]]'s [[Grass Valley, California|Grass Valley]], over 60 per cent of the population was Cornish. It has a tradition of [[Carol (music)|carols]] stemming from the Cornish who settled the area as gold miners in the 19th century. The carols have become "the identity of the town", some of the members of the Grass Valley Cornish Carol Choir are descendants of the original Cornish settlers.{{citation |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/immig_emig/england/cornwall/article_3.shtml |title=I’m alright Jack > The Cornish Diaspora |work=BBC News |accessdate=5 July 2009 |page=3 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123114543/http://www.bbc.co.uk/legacies/immig_emig/england/cornwall/article_3.shtml |archivedate=23 November 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Most migratory Cornish to the United States were classified as English or British, meaning that the precise number of [[Cornish American]]s is difficult to estimate. The aggregate number of immigrants from Cornwall to the United States before World War I is suggested to be around 100,000. == Culture == {{Further|Culture of Cornwall}} [[File:Stpiraninpenwith.JPG|thumb|left|alt=A street lined with shops is filled with hundreds of people. In the foreground are children wearing black vests each one defaced with a large white cross. The children surround a fiddler. In the background are spectators.|[[St. Piran's Day]] is an annual patronal [[Cornish festivals|Cornish festival]] celebrating Cornish culture and history every 5 March.]] The survival of a distinct [[Culture of Cornwall|Cornish culture]] has been attributed to Cornwall's geographic isolation.{{harvnb|Minahan|2002|p=480}} Contemporaneously, the underlying notion of Cornish culture is that it is distinct from the [[culture of England]], despite its [[anglicisation]], and that it is instead part of a Celtic tradition. According to American academic [[Paul Robert Magocsi]], modern-day Cornish activists have claimed several [[Victorian era]] inventions including the [[Cornish engine]], [[Christmas carol]]s, [[rugby football]] and [[brass band]]s as part of this Cornish tradition. Cornish cultural tradition is most strongly associated with the people's most historical occupation, mining,{{harvnb|Minahan|2002|pp=480–481}}. an aspect of Cornish history and culture that has influenced its cuisine, symbols and identity. Cornwall has [[List of Cornish saints|its own tradition of Christian saints]], derived from Celtic extraction, that have given rise to localised dedications. [[Saint Piran]] is the 5th century Christian abbot, supposedly of Irish origin, who is patron saint of both tin miners and Cornwall.{{citation |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cornwall/uncovered/stories/march2004/stpirans_2004.shtml |work=BBC News |title=St Pirans Day Celebrations |date=March 2004 |accessdate=2 September 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100427012942/http://www.bbc.co.uk/cornwall/uncovered/stories/march2004/stpirans_2004.shtml |archivedate=27 April 2010 |df=dmy-all }} According to popular mythology, Piran, an Irish scholar who studied Christianity in [[Ancient Rome]] was to be drowned in the [[Irish Sea]] by the [[High King of Ireland|High Kings of Ireland]], but instead floated across to [[Perranporth]] in Cornwall by the will of God to preach the [[ministry of Jesus]]. [[Saint Piran's Flag]], a centred white cross on a black field,{{citation |url=http://www.flaginstitute.org/index.php?location=10&flagtype=county&flagid=100 |work=Flag Institute |title=Cornwall; St. Pirran's Cross |accessdate=2 September 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090531112300/http://www.flaginstitute.org/index.php?location=10&flagtype=county&flagid=100 |archivedate=31 May 2009 |df=dmy-all }} was described as the "Standard of Cornwall" in 1838 and was re-introduced by [[Celtic Revival]]ists thereafter as a [[List of English flags|county flag]] of Cornwall. It has been seized upon by the Cornish people as a symbol of their identity, displayed on cars and flying from buildings including those of [[Cornwall Council]].{{citation |url=http://www.cornishstudies.com/index.php?q=node/10 |publisher=cornishstudies.com |first=Susan |last=Witterick |date=7 April 2007 |accessdate=1 September 2009 |title=How far has the "Cornish Revival" affected modern Cornwall? |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008211307/http://www.cornishstudies.com/index.php?q=node%2F10 |archivedate=8 October 2011 |df=dmy-all }} [[St Piran's Day]] is an annual patronal [[fête]], and the pre-eminent [[Cornish festivals|Cornish festival]] celebrating Cornish culture and history on 5 March. === Language === {{Further|Cornish language}} {{See also|Anglo-Cornish|West Country dialects|List of Cornish dialect words}} [[File:Penzansagasdynerghcrop.jpeg|right|thumb|A [[welcome sign]] to [[Penzance]], in the English and [[Cornish language|Cornish]] languages]] The [[Cornish language]] is derived from the [[Brythonic languages|Brythonic]] branch of the [[Insular Celtic languages]]. It is closely related to the [[Breton language]], and to a lesser extent shares commonalities with the [[Welsh language]],{{harvnb|Minahan|2002|p=481}}. although they are not [[mutual intelligibility|mutually intelligible]].{{harvnb|Hechter|1999|p=195}}. The language functioned as a community language in Cornwall until a [[language shift]] to the English language was completed during the late 18th century. The demise of the Cornish language is attributed to English cultural influence, particularly the political and religious dominance of the [[English Reformation]] and the [[Act of Uniformity 1549]] which outlawed all church services within the Kingdom of England that were not in English. The exact date of the death of using the Cornish language is unclear and disputed, but popularly it is claimed that the last [[Monolingualism|monolingual]] Cornish speaker was [[Dolly Pentreath]], a [[Mousehole]] resident who died in 1777.{{harvnb|Tanner|2006|pp=234–235}}.{{harvnb|Ellis|1974|pp=115–118}}. The revival of Cornish began in 1904 when [[Henry Jenner]], a Celtic language enthusiast, published his book ''Handbook of the Cornish Language''.{{harvnb|Ball|Fife|1993|p=644}}. He based his work on Cornish as it was spoken in the 18th century, although his pupil [[Robert Morton Nance]], with his orthography, [[Unified Cornish]], later steered the revival more towards the [[Middle Cornish]] that had been used in the 16th century, before the language became more heavily influenced by English.{{harvnb|Minahan|2002|p=486}}. This set the tone for the next few decades; as the revival gained pace, learners of the language disagreed on which style of Cornish to use, and a number of competing orthographies—Unified Cornish, [[Unified Cornish Revised]], [[Modern Cornish]], [[Kernewek Kemmyn]]—were in use by the end of the 20th century. A [[Standard Written Form|standard written form]] was agreed in 2008.{{citation |title=Standard Cornish spelling agreed |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cornwall/7408686.stm |work=BBC News |date=19 May 2008 |accessdate=10 September 2009 }} Cornish is a restored and living [[modern language]], but most of its speakers are enthusiasts, persons who have learned the language through private study. Cornish speakers are geographically dispersed, meaning there is no part of Cornwall where it is spoken as a community language. As of 2009, it is taught in fifty primary schools,{{citation |title=The Cornish: They revolted in 1497, now they're at it again |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/the-cornish-they-revolted-in-1497-now-theyre-at-it-again-1782535.html |work=The Independent |first=Emily |last=Dugan |date=6 June 2009 |accessdate=10 September 2009 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090909182150/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/this-britain/the-cornish-they-revolted-in-1497-now-theyre-at-it-again-1782535.html |archivedate=9 September 2009 |df=dmy-all }} although regular broadcast in Cornish is limited to a weekly bilingual programme on [[BBC Radio Cornwall]].{{harvnb|Ball|Fife|1993|p=645}}. Daily life in Cornwall therefore is conducted in the English language, albeit with [[List of Cornish dialect words|some regional peculiarities]]. ''Legends of the Fall'', a novella by American author [[Jim Harrison]], detailing the lives of a [[Cornish American]] family in the early 20th century, contains several Cornish language terms. These were also included in the [[Academy Award]] winning [[Legends of the Fall|film of the same name]] starring [[Anthony Hopkins]] as Col. William Ludlow and [[Brad Pitt]] as Tristan Ludlow.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/?id=VgBtaDT-evYC&pg=PA204&dq=cornish+legends+of+the+fall#v=onepage&q=cornish%20legends%20of%20the%20fall&f=false |title=The Celtic Languages in Contact |first= Hildegard L. C. |last=Tristram |date=2007 |publisher=Universitätsverlag Potsdam |isbn=978-3-940793-07-2 |via=Google Books |accessdate=20 April 2012}} === Literature and folklore === {{Main|Cornish literature}} {{See also|Matter of Britain|Historia Regum Britanniae}} [[Early Middle Ages|Early medieval]] Cornwall was associated with the [[Matter of Britain]], a [[national myth]] recounting a legendary Celtic history of Brittonic warriors, including [[King Arthur]].{{harvnb|Minahan|2002|p=482}}. The Matter of Britain was supported by texts such as the ''[[Historia Regum Britanniae]]'', a [[pseudohistory|pseudohistorical]] account of the history of the ancient Britons, written in the mid-12th century by [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]].{{Harvnb|Bradshaw|Roberts|2003|p=1}}. The ''Historia Regum Britanniae'' chronicled the lives of [[List of legendary kings of Britain|legendary kings of the Britons]] in a narrative spanning a time of two thousand years, beginning with the [[Troy|Trojans]] founding the ancient British nation and continuing until the Anglo-Saxon invasion of Britain in the 5th century forced the Celtic Britons to the west coast, namely [[Wales]] and Cornwall.{{cite journal |url=http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_089/89_055_066.pdf |title=The term "Great Britain" in the Middle Ages |last=Hay |first=Denys |authorlink=Denys Hay |journal=Proceedings of the Society of Antiquaries of Scotland |number=81 |year=1958 |pages=55–66 |accessdate=19 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090205041736/http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_089/89_055_066.pdf |archivedate=5 February 2009}} Although broadly thought of as a work of fiction, Geoffrey of Monmouth's work had a lasting effect upon the identity of the Cornish.{{harvnb|Thomas|2005|p=355}}. His "historical construct" characterised the ancient Britons as heroes, which later helped Celtic revivalists to redefine Cornishness as an identity closely related to ancient heroic Celtic folklore. Another strand of Cornish folklore is derived from tales of seafaring [[piracy|pirates]] and [[Smuggling|smugglers]] who thrived in and around Cornwall from the early modern period through to the 19th century. Cornish pirates exploited both their knowledge of the Cornish coastline as well as its sheltered creeks and hidden anchorages. For many [[fishing village]]s, loot and contraband provided by pirates supported a strong and secretive [[underground economy]] in Cornwall. [[Legendary creature]]s that appear in Cornish folklore include [[Bucca (mythological creature)|buccas]], [[Knocker (folklore)|knockers]] and [[Pixie|piskies]].{{harvnb|Steves|2007|p=253}}. Tales of these creatures are thought to have developed as [[supernatural]] explanations for the frequent and deadly [[cave-in]]s that occurred during 18th-century Cornish tin mining, or else a creation of the oxygen-starved minds of exhausted miners who returned from the underground. === Performing and visual arts === {{Further|Cornish dance|Music of Cornwall}} [[File:Red obby oss maiden 20050502.jpg|thumb|right|The [['Obby 'Oss festival]] is a Cornish May Day festival celebrated in [[Padstow]].]] [[Celtic cross]]es, many dating from between the 7th and 15th centuries, are found in Cornwall and have been used as inspiration in modern and contemporary Cornish visual arts.{{citation |url=http://www.intocornwall.com/features/crosses-holy-wells.asp |title=Crosses, Cornish Saints and Holy Wells in Cornwall |work=Into Cornwall.com |accessdate=10 September 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507075621/http://www.intocornwall.com/features/crosses-holy-wells.asp |archivedate=7 May 2009 |df=dmy-all }}{{citation |url=http://www.krowskernewek.com/celtic-cross-history.htm |title=A Brief History of the Celtic Cross in Cornwall |first=Alex |last=Everitt |work=Krowskernewek.com |accessdate=10 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090313090941/http://www.krowskernewek.com/celtic-cross-history.htm |archivedate=13 March 2009 |df=dmy }} In the 1780s, [[John Opie]] was the first Cornish-born painter to gain widespread attention; his work was exhibited at the [[Royal Academy]] and he was described by [[Joshua Reynolds]] as "like [[Caravaggio]] and [[Diego Velázquez|Velázquez]] in one".{{citation |url=http://www.artnet.com/library/06/0636/T063630.asp |title=Opie, John |work=[[The Grove Dictionary of Art]] |via=artnet.com |accessdate=10 September 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020919170107/http://www.artnet.com/library/06/0636/T063630.asp |archivedate=19 September 2002}} Artists who appreciated the quality of Cornwall's [[Sunlight|natural light]], such as [[J. M. W. Turner]], began to visit, with more following after the opening of the [[Great Western Railway]], including [[James Abbott McNeill Whistler|Whistler]] and [[Walter Sickert|Sickert]]. [[Stanhope Forbes]] and [[Frank Bramley]] settled in Cornwall in the 1880s, establishing the [[Newlyn School]] of painting ''[[en plein air]]''. By the 1920s, the [[ceramic art|ceramicist]] [[Bernard Leach]] was established at [[St Ives, Cornwall|St Ives]], and the [[St Ives School]] for abstract artists formed there, influenced by [[naive art|naive]] painters such as [[Alfred Wallis]], and involving the work of [[Ben Nicholson]], his wife [[Barbara Hepworth]], [[Naum Gabo]] and [[Patrick Heron]]. === Religion === {{See also|List of Cornish saints|Christianity in Cornwall}} Anciently, the religion of the Cornish Britons was [[Celtic polytheism]], a [[paganism|pagan]], [[Animism|animistic]] faith, assumed to be led by [[Druid]]s in full or in part.{{harvnb|Hitchins|Drew|1824|pp=348–349}}. [[Early Christianity]] is thought to have existed in Cornwall during the 1st century, but limited to individual travellers and visitors, possibly including [[Priscillian]], a Galician theologian who may have been exiled to the [[Isles of Scilly]]. [[Celtic Christianity]] was introduced to Cornwall in the year 520 by [[Saint Petroc]], a Brython from the kingdom of [[Glywysing]], and other missionaries from Wales, as well as by [[Gaels|Gaelic]] monks and holy women from Ireland; this "formative period" has left a legacy of granite [[high cross]] monuments throughout Cornwall. Dedications to many different [[List of Cornish saints|Cornish saints]] can also be traced to this period. In the Middle Ages, Roman Catholicism was dominant in Cornwall, and even in the 17th century the Cornish were "fervently Roman Catholic", slow to accept the [[Protestant Reformation]], according to some scholars.{{harvnb|Minahan|2000|pp=180–181}}. The adoption of [[Anglicanism]] was, eventually, near-universal in Cornwall and facilitated the [[anglicisation]] of the Cornish people. A variety of dissenting congregations such as the Quakers and Baptists were to be found in certain districts. Through a combination of tours of Cornwall by [[John Wesley]], rural isolation and compatibility with Cornish tastes and sensibilities, [[Wesleyanism|Methodism]], an evangelical revival movement within the [[Church of England]],{{citation |url=http://www.methodist-central-hall.org.uk/history/WhatisMethodism.htm |title=About the Methodist Church |work=Methodist Central Hall Westminster |accessdate=31 December 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070121041402/http://www.methodist-central-hall.org.uk/history/WhatisMethodism.htm |archivedate=21 January 2007 |deadurl=yes}}{{citation |url=http://www.umcwfb.org/_ABOUTUS/about_us_ourstory.htm |title=What We Believe; founder of the United Methodist Church |work=United Methodist Church of Whitefish Bay |accessdate=1 August 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080325213036/http://www.umcwfb.org/_aboutus/about_us_ourstory.htm |archivedate=25 March 2008 |df=dmy-all }} became the form of Christianity practised by the majority of the population all over Cornwall during the 19th century.{{harvnb|Tregidga|2000|p=17}}. During this time other kinds of Methodist churches appeared such as the Bible Christians and there were also Evangelical and [[Oxford Movement|Anglo-Catholic]] revivals within the Church of England. === Cuisine === {{Further|Cornish cuisine}} [[File:Cornish pasty.jpeg|thumb|right|alt=A light brown pastry case is on a white plate|A [[pasty|Cornish pasty]]]] Cornish cuisine is a regional variety of [[British cuisine]], strongly rooted in a tradition of using local produce,{{harvnb|Trewin|Woolfitt|2005|p=6}}. which is used to create relatively simple dishes.{{harvnb|Trewin|Woolfitt|2005|p=8}}. Most prominent in Cornish cuisine is the [[pasty]] (sometimes known as the Cornish pasty) made from diced beef, potato, onion and swede (commonly called 'turnip' by the Cornish), enclosed within a pastry crust and then baked.{{harvnb|Tregellas|2008|p=16}}. One idea of its origins suggests that it evolved as a portable lunch for Cornish miners, the crust serving as a disposable handle that could be held by a miner's hand without soiling the filling. Fish was an important element of the Cornish diet, but international [[commercial fishing]] was also well established by the 16th century, and tons of [[sardine|pilchards]] were exported from Cornwall to France, Italy and Spain every year. [[Stargazy pie]] is an occasional festive Cornish dish with the heads of fish standing on their tails, originally [[pilchards]], piercing a pastry crust. The [[saffron bun]], also known as the tea treat bun, is a sweet bread with its origins in Cornwall. === Sport === {{Main|Sport in Cornwall}} [[File:DSCF3394 CROP.jpg|thumb|right|upright|alt=Two men in combat appear on a green lawn in front of a shrubbery. Both men are wearing dark coloured shorts and cream coloured tops. One man has a tactical advantage, and is throwing his opponent head-first towards the ground.|[[Cornish wrestling]] is a contact sport, a style of folk martial arts, that has its origins in Cornwall]] With its comparatively small, rural population, major contribution by the Cornish to national [[sport in the United Kingdom]] has been limited.{{harvnb|Clegg|2005|p=10}}. There are no teams affiliated to the [[Cornwall County Football Association]] that play in the [[Football League]] of [[England and Wales]], and the [[Cornwall County Cricket Club]] plays as one of the [[minor counties of English cricket]]. Viewed as an "important identifier of ethnic affiliation", [[rugby union]] has become a sport strongly tied with notions of Cornishness,{{harvnb|Harvey|2002|p=221}}. and since the 20th century, [[rugby union in Cornwall]] has emerged as one of the most popular spectator and team sports in Cornwall, with professional Cornish rugby footballers being described as a "formidable force", "naturally independent, both in thought and deed, yet paradoxically staunch English patriots whose top players have represented England with pride and passion".{{citation |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/club/3247717/Cornish-rugby-union-celebrate-125-years-of-pride-and-passion---but-are-they-the-lost-tribe-Rugby.html |work=The Daily Telegraph |title=Cornish rugby union celebrate 125 years of pride and passion – but are they the lost tribe? |first=Brendan |last=Gallagher |date=23 October 2008 |accessdate=7 September 2009 |location=London |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081027084935/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/rugbyunion/club/3247717/Cornish-rugby-union-celebrate-125-years-of-pride-and-passion---but-are-they-the-lost-tribe-Rugby.html |archivedate=27 October 2008 |df=dmy-all }} In 1985, sports journalist [[Alan Gibson]] made a direct connection between love of rugby in Cornwall and the ancient parish games of hurling and wrestling that existed for centuries before rugby officially began. [[Cornish wrestling]] (also known as Wrasslin') is a regional, folk style of [[grappling]] or martial arts. The Cornish Wrestling Association was formed in 1923, to standardise the rules of the sport and to promote Cornish wrestling throughout Cornwall and the world.{{citation |url=http://www.cornishwrestling.co.uk/ |work=cornishwrestling.co.uk |title=Cornish Wrestling Association |accessdate=2 September 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517201611/http://www.cornishwrestling.co.uk/ |archivedate=17 May 2008 |df=dmy-all }} Together with [[Cornish hurling]] (a localised form of [[medieval football]]), Wrasslin' has been promoted as a distinctly Celtic game, tied closely with Cornish identity. [[Surfing]] was popularised in Cornwall during the late 20th century, and has since become readily associated with Cornishness.{{citation |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/cornwall/surfing/surfinguide.shtml |work=BBC News |title=The good surf guide to Cornwall |first=Simon |last=Alexander |accessdate=4 September 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091205080033/http://www.bbc.co.uk/cornwall/surfing/surfinguide.shtml |archivedate=5 December 2009 |df=dmy-all }} The waves around the Cornish coastline are created by low pressure systems from the Atlantic Ocean which unleash powerful swells eastwards creating multiple, excellent surfing conditions in some parts of the coast of Cornwall. [[Newquay]], one of Britain's "premier surfing towns", regularly hosts world championship surfing events. == Institutions and politics == {{Main|Politics of Cornwall}} [[File:Lostwithiel - the Guildhall - geograph.org.uk - 571361.jpg|thumb|right|The surviving part of the former ''Duchy Palace'' in [[Lostwithiel]], the former administrative seat of the [[Duke of Cornwall]] from c.1265 to 1874.]] [[File:Old County Hall Truro.jpeg|thumb|right|The Old County Hall in [[Truro]], the former seat of [[Cornwall Council]].]] The [[politics of Cornwall]] take place within a wider national political framework of a [[constitutional monarchy]], in which the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom's monarch]] is [[head of state]] and the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] is the [[head of government]], and the supranational framework of the [[European Union]]. Cornish politics are marked by a long tradition of Liberalism. Important historical institutions were the [[Duchy of Cornwall]] and the Cornish [[Stannary Courts and Parliaments]]. The Stannary court administered [[Equity (law)|equity]], through special laws and legal exemptions, for all matters relating to the tin mines and tin trade in Cornwall. Cornish miners were effectively exempt from the jurisdiction of the law courts at [[Palace of Westminster|Westminster]], except "in such cases as should affect land, life or limb". The ancient privileges of the Stannary Courts and Parliaments were confirmed by successive [[Royal Charter]]s in the Middle Ages, including those administered by Kings [[John of England|John]], [[Edward I of England|Edward I]] and [[Edward III of England]]. As the tin mines of Cornwall lost their economic importance during the 18th and 19th centuries, so the Stannary institutions lost political power. The last Stannary parliament was held at [[Truro]] in 1752, and continued, by adjournments, until 11 September 1753. As in the rest of Great Britain, the [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Party]] dominated Cornish politics during the 19th century,{{harvnb|Tregidga|2000|p=9}}. although Socialism gained limited support in western Cornwall,{{harvnb|Tregidga|2000|p=30}}. and the [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] won preference after World War I.{{harvnb|Tregidga|2000|p=25}}. Nationalism (or [[Regionalism (politics)|regionalism]]){{harvnb|Schrijver|2006|p=106}}. in Cornwall traces its roots to the [[Irish Home Rule bills]] of the late 19th century,{{citation|last=Tregidga|first=Garry|authorlink=Garry Tregidga|date=Spring 1999|title=Devolution for the Duchy – The Liberal Party and the Nationalist Movement in Cornwall|journal=Journal of Liberal Democrat History|publisher=[[Liberal Democrat History Group]]|issue=22|pages=21–23|url=http://www.liberalhistory.org.uk/uploads/22_tregidga_devolution_for_the_duchy.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090617142154/http://www.liberalhistory.org.uk/uploads/22_tregidga_devolution_for_the_duchy.pdf|archivedate=17 June 2009|df=dmy-all}} and is represented by the [[Cornish self-government movement]], a political action group that is predominantly organised to promote Cornwall as the national homeland of the Cornish, campaign for [[devolution]], and win it the status as a fifth [[countries of the United Kingdom|country within the UK]] rather than outright [[separatism]]. More "militant" variants of Cornish nationalism however claim that because of historical constitutional peculiarities regarding the [[constitutional status of Cornwall|status of Cornwall]], the [[law of the European Union]] does or should not have jurisdiction over Cornwall until Cornish sovereignty is recognised. Popularisation of Cornish nationalism is attributed to a Celtic cultural revival in Cornwall which itself began with a newed interested in the Cornish language in the 1920s.{{harvnb|Minahan|2002|p=483}}. The revival of the Cornish language encouraged a parallel revival of Celtic traditions, which by the 1970s had spurred on Cornish nationalism. The United Kingdom's entry into the [[European Economic Community]] in 1973 prompted claims that the Cornish should be granted their own [[devolution|devolved]] [[national assembly]]—the [[Cornish Assembly]]—comparable to that of the [[National Assembly for Wales]]. [[Mebyon Kernow]] is a [[Left-wing politics|left-wing political party]] based in Cornwall, founded in 1951.{{citation |url=http://www.mebyonkernow.org/?q=history_the_history_of_mk |work=Mebyon Kernow |accessdate=2 September 2009 |title=The History of MK |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607202630/http://www.mebyonkernow.org/?q=history_the_history_of_mk |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }} Its main objective is attaining greater autonomy for Cornwall through the establishment of a legislative Cornish Assembly.{{citation |url=http://www.mebyonkernow.org/?q=node/51 |work=Mebyon Kernow |accessdate=2 September 2009 |title=The Core Values of Mebyon Kernow – The Party For Cornwall |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802005401/http://www.mebyonkernow.org/?q=node%2F51 |archivedate=2 August 2009 |df=dmy-all }} As at 2009 Mebyon Kernow has no Members of Parliament elected to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom]], and in the [[United Kingdom local elections, 2009]] received 4 per cent of votes to elect councillors to [[Cornwall Council]], behind the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] (34 per cent), [[Liberal Democrats (UK)|Liberal Democrats]] (28 per cent), and [[Independent (politician)|Independents]] (23 per cent){{citation |url=http://democracy.cornwall.gov.uk/mgElectionResults.aspx?ID=1&RPID=270582 |work=Cornwall Council |title=Elections – Thursday, 4th June, 2009 |accessdate=2 September 2009}} Since the [[2009 structural changes to local government in England]], Cornwall Council has been a [[Unitary authorities of England|unitary authority]],{{citation |url=http://www.cornwall.gov.uk/Default.aspx?page=1747 |work=Cornwall Council |accessdate=3 July 2009 |title=Council and democracy |date=27 May 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090725075331/http://www.cornwall.gov.uk/Default.aspx?page=1747 |archivedate=25 July 2009 |df=dmy-all }}{{citation |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cornwall/7129905.stm |title=Unitary status agreed for council |work=BBC News |accessdate=3 July 2009 |date=5 December 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129231521/http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/cornwall/7129905.stm |archivedate=29 January 2009 |df=dmy-all }} serving as the sole executive, [[Deliberation|deliberative]], and [[legislative]] body responsible for local policy, setting [[council tax]], and allocating budgets. Following the Cornwall Council election in May 2013, the council remained as "no overall control", with the Independent politicians becoming the largest grouping on the council through a modest gain of councillors from the previous election. The Liberal Democrats remained the second largest party after losing 2 councillors and the Conservatives slipped to third after losing over a third of their councillors. The Labour Party (+8), UKIP (+6), and the Green Party (+1) all gained seats, with UKIP and the Greens entering Cornwall Council for the first time. Mebyon Kernow had 6 councilors prior to the election, having added 2 since the 2009 election, their total following the election was reduced to 4.{{cite web |url=https://democracy.cornwall.gov.uk/mgElectionResults.aspx?ID=15&RPID=4025451 |title=Election results by party, 2 May 2013 |date=2 May 2013 |work=Cornwall Council |accessdate=16 February 2017}} In the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]] all Cornish seats were won by the Conservatives. This was repeated in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 general election.]] == See also == {{Portal|Cornwall}} * [[List of people from Cornwall]] * [[List of topics related to Cornwall]] Michell Whitley, 1895) * {{citation|title=The Liberal Party in South-west Britain since 1918: political decline, dormancy and rebirth|publisher=Presses Université Laval|year=2000|last=Tregidga |first=Garry |isbn=978-0-85989-679-5}} * {{citation|title=Gourmet Cornwall|first1=Carol|last1=Trewin|first2=Adam|last2=Woolfitt|publisher=Alison Hodge|year=2005|isbn=978-0-906720-39-4}} * {{citation|title=The 1549 Rebellions and the Making of Early Modern England |first=Andy|last=Wood|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2007|isbn=978-0-521-83206-9}} * {{citation|title=Rebels and Rulers, 1500–1660; vol. 2: Provincial rebellion: Revolutionary Civil Wars, 1560–1660|first=Pérez|last=Zagorín|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=1982|isbn=978-0-521-28712-8}} {{refend}} == Further reading == *Miles, Sibella ''Original Cornish Ballads: chiefly founded on stories humorously told by Mr. Tregellas in his popular lectures on "Peculiarities" : to which are appended some drafts of kindred character from the portfolio of the editress: the whole prefixed by an introductory essay on the peculiar characteristics of the Cornish peasantry''. London: Simpkin, Marshall, 1846. == External links == {{Commons category|People of Cornwall}} * [http://www.cornwall.gov.uk/ www.cornwall.gov.uk], the website of [[Cornwall Council]] * [http://www.cornishculture.co.uk/ www.cornishculture.co.uk], an online guide to Cornish Celtic culture {{British peoples}} {{Celtic nations}} {{Good article}} [[Category:Cornish people| ]] [[Category:Brythonic Celts]] [[Category:Celtic ethnic groups]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
'''Dular Osor Chaoke''' ({{zh|s=杜拉尔·敖斯尔·朝克|p=Dùlā'ěr Áosī'ěr Zhāokè}}; born 1958) is a [[China|Chinese]] linguist at the [[Chinese Academy of Social Sciences]].<ref name="SFChron">{{citation|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2009-10-11/news/17183468_1_reindeer-herders-resettlement|first=Henry|last=Sanderson|date=2009-10-11|title=Chinese nomads lose identity|periodical=The San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=2011-04-20}}</ref> His primary area of study is on the [[Tungusic languages]], especially his native [[Evenki language]].<ref name="CRI">{{citation|url=http://gb.cri.cn/8606/2006/03/11/146@941700.htm|author=龚万鹏|date=2006-03-11|title=朝克：从牧场主到语言学家的人大代表|periodical=China Radio International|accessdate=2011-04-23}}</ref>
==Personal life and education== Chaoke was born in Nantun (南屯), [[Evenk Autonomous Banner]] in northeastern [[Inner Mongolia]]. "Osor" is the personal name of his father, while "Dular" is that of his ancestors, i.e. surname. He grew up speaking Evenki at home and attending a [[Mongolian language|Mongolian]]-[[medium of instruction|medium]] school, but says he did not become fully fluent in [[Mandarin Chinese]] until he graduated from high school.<ref name="CRI"/>
After his high school graduation, Chaoke spent some years as a herder; he then became part of the "Class of 1978" (those who took the first offering of the [[National Higher Education Entrance Examination]] after it was reinstated that year) and with his results attained admission to the Central University for Nationalities ([[Minzu University of China]]) Department of Linguistics. He wrote his senior thesis on the structure of the Evenki language.<ref name="CRI"/>
Chaoke is married to Wang Lizhen (汪丽珍), who is of [[Manchus|Manchu]] ethnicity. The rest of his family are also highly educated, with four doctorates among them; his younger sister Kalina did her Ph.D. in anthropology at the Central University for Nationalities, while his younger brother Chogja did his at [[Chiba University]] in [[Chiba, Chiba|Chiba]], Japan.<ref name="CRI"/>
==Career== Following his graduation, Chaoke took up a position as a researcher at his alma mater in 1982.<ref name="Sina">{{citation|url=http://news.sina.com.cn/o/2008-10-13/092114566129s.shtml|title=朝克:语言天赋令人折服|periodical=Sina News|date=2008-10-13|accessdate=2011-04-22}}</ref> In 1988, he received a Japanese government scholarship, and departed his home country for [[Japan]] to enroll in a doctoral program at the [[Tokyo University of Foreign Studies]]. He quickly completed his coursework there and began work on his thesis, and also began extending his impressive publication record to Japanese, with ten papers and two books.<ref name="CRI"/> In total from 1982 to 2006 he published 120 papers and eighteen books, a total output estimated at roughly six million characters.<ref name="Sina"/>
Outside of academia, Chaoke has served as a representative to the ninth, tenth, and eleventh [[National People's Congress]]es. He saved a portion of the money from his Japanese government scholarship, and upon his return to China used it to establish an "Evenk Ethnic Culture Village" in the Evenk Autonomous Banner.<ref name="Sina"/>
==Selected works== *{{citation |first=D. O. |last=Chaoke |year=2009 |title=''《鄂温克语参考语法》'' |trans-title=Evenki Grammar Reference |location=Beijing |publisher=中国社会科学出版社 [China Social Sciences Publishing House] |isbn=978-7-5004-8143-0}}
==References== {{reflist}}
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Chaoke, D. O.}} [[Category:1958 births]] [[Category:Linguists from China]] [[Category:Minzu University of China alumni]] [[Category:People from Hulunbuir]] [[Category:Tokyo University of Foreign Studies alumni]] [[Category:Tungusologists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People's Republic of China politicians from Inner Mongolia]] [[Category:Writers from Inner Mongolia]] [[Category:Scientists from Inner Mongolia]] [[Category:Evenks]]
[[zh:朝克]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |image = |name= Richard P. "Dick" Guidry |caption= |office=[[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana State Representative for Lafourche Parish]] |term_start=1950 (?) |term_end=1954 (?) |term_start2=1964 |term_end2=1976 |preceded2=Dudley A. Bernard
Woolen J. Falgout |succeeded2=L. G. LaPlante, Jr. |birth_date={{birth date|1929|9|22}} |birth_place= [[Galliano, Louisiana|Galliano]], [[Lafourche Parish, Louisiana|Lafourche Parish]]
[[Louisiana]], USA |death_date={{death date and age|2014|3|26|1929|9|22}} |death_place= |spouse= Phyllis Guidry |children= 6 |residence= [[Galliano, Louisiana]], U.S. |resting_place= |party= [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] |occupation=[[Business]]man |religion= Roman Catholic{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} |alma_mater=Golden Meadow High School in [[Golden Meadow, Louisiana]]}} :''For the [[Louisiana]] advocate of the French language, see [[Richard Guidry]]''l for another [[Louisiana House of Representatives|Louisiana state representative]], see ''[[Jesse J. Guidry]]''. '''Richard P. Guidry''', known as '''Dick Guidry''' (September 22, 1929 – March 26, 2014) was a [[business]]man from [[Galliano, Louisiana|Galliano]], [[Louisiana]], who was a [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] former member of the [[Louisiana House of Representatives]] for [[Lafourche Parish, Louisiana|Lafourche Parish]].{{cite web|url=http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf |title=Membership in the Louisiana House of Representatives, 1812-2016 |publisher=house.louisiana.gov |accessdate=May 22, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006105414/http://house.louisiana.gov/H_PDFdocs/HouseMembership_History_CURRENT.pdf |archivedate=October 6, 2014 |df= }} He is considered the youngest member ever elected to the Louisiana House. ==Political life== On February 1, 2014, less than two months before his death, Guidry and seven others were inducted into the [[Louisiana Political Museum and Hall of Fame]] in [[Winnfield, Louisiana|Winnfield]]. In the same ceremony, Guidry's [[Louisiana State Senate|state senate]] colleague, [[Harvey Peltier, Jr.]], of [[Thibodaux, Louisiana|Thibodaux]], received [[Posthumous recognition|posthumous]] induction.{{cite web|url=http://bossierpress.com/2013/10/02/whos-famous/|title=Who's famous?, October 2, 2013|publisher=''[[Bossier Press-Tribune]]''|accessdate=October 2, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131002233027/http://bossierpress.com/2013/10/02/whos-famous/|archivedate=October 2, 2013|df=}} The Hall of Fame claims that Guidry was elected to the House by a margin of seventeen votes in 1952, when he was twenty-three. He served from Lafourche Parish from 1952 to 1956. [[Francis Dugas]], a lawyer from Thibodaux, held a House seat from Lafourche Parish from 1956 to 1960. Guidry thereafter took office in May 1964 and left the House permanently in 1976 after three more terms. In the first ever [[nonpartisan blanket primary]] held on November 1, 1975, Guidry did not run again. In his last term from 1972 to 1976, he served alongside future [[U.S. Representative]] [[Billy Tauzin]] of [[Louisiana's 3rd congressional district]] and later [[Louisiana State Senate|State Senator]] [[Leonard J. Chabert]]. In 1966, Guidry and [[Louisiana State Senate|State Senator]] [[Dudley J. LeBlanc]] of [[Vermilion Parish, Louisiana|Vermilion Parish]], who made a fortune in the [[patent medicine]] [[Hadacol]], challenged U.S. Representative [[Edwin E. Willis]] in the Democratic primary in the Third Congressional District.{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/1592776/|title=Everyone gets into state politics|publisher=''Lake Charles American Press''|date=August 12, 1966|location=[[Lake Charles, Louisiana|Lake Charles]], [[Louisiana]]|page=15|accessdate=September 11, 2014}} Willis prevailed and then defeated in the [[general election]] the Republican candidate, [[Hall Lyons]] of [[Lafayette, Louisiana|Lafayette]], but it was Willis's last term in the seat, for he was unseated in the 1968 primary by [[Patrick T. Caffery]]. In 1970, Representative Guidry obtained designation of the South Louisiana Tidal Water Control Levee District, signed into law that year by [[governor of Louisiana|Governor]] [[John McKeithen]]. In 1978, the entity was renamed the South Lafourche Levee District. Located in Galliano, the hurricane protection system consists of forty-eight miles of ring levee, 33,400 acres within the flood protection system, six pumping stations, and total acreage of nearly 440,000.{{cite web|url=http://slid.org/historyofslid.html|title=History of South Lafourche Levee System|publisher=slid.org|accessdate=October 3, 2013}} In 1971, Guidry announced his candidacy for [[Lieutenant Governor of Louisiana|lieutenant governor]] but withdrew from consideration after he raised less than a fifth of the $500,000 that he said would be necessary to mount a competitive campaign. Another candidate for lieutenant governor, [[Louisiana State Senate|state Senator]] [[Sixty Rayburn]] of [[Bogalusa, Louisiana|Bogalusa]] also pulled out of the race for fund-raising problems."Guidry Quits," ''[[Minden Press-Herald]],'' August 11, 1971, p. 1. On April 29, 1975, in a "personal privileges" speech on the floor of the Louisiana House, Guidry, considered a [[Conservative Democrat]], decried the [[Communism|communist]] takeover of the former [[South Vietnam]]. He became so outraged over the turn of fortunes against the United States in Southeast Asia that he questioned whether the country could survive until its 300th birthday. Guidry said that voters have the mentality of "a fourteen-year-old". He suggested that actress [[Jane Fonda]] and former [[Black Panthers]] figure [[Eldridge Cleaver]], before the latter's conversion to [[Conservative (politics)|conservatism]], were "re-gloating and celebrating" the communist triumph."Guidry predicts downfall", ''Minden Press-Herald,'' April 30, 1975, pg. 1. In 2012, at the Former Legislators Day ceremony in the [[Louisiana State Capitol]], [[Woody Jenkins]], owner of the ''Central City News'' in [[Central City, Louisiana|Central]] in [[East Baton Rouge Parish, Louisiana|East Baton Rouge Parish]], photographed many of his former colleagues, including Guidry. The photographs are posted on the Internet.{{cite web|url=http://centralcitynews.smugmug.com/Politics/Louisiana-Legislative-Reunion/22787667_LDJNv7/1828015354_5BJPw6g#!i=1828015354&k=5BJPw6g|title=Former Louisiana Legislators Day|publisher=''Central City News''|accessdate=October 3, 2013}} ==Theater owner== Guidry owned the Jet Drive-in Theater, located on [[Louisiana Highway 1]] in [[Cut Off, Louisiana|Cut Off]] and the Jet Cinema in Galliano. In the 1980s, the Jet Drive-In was closed because of the falling of the screen tower. For years a popular meeting place for young people, the Jet could accommodate five hundred cars, had a screen 150 feet in height, and a snack bar specializing in chili. Guidry also owned several other area theaters; the Jet became so popular that it drove most of his competitors out of business.{{cite web|url=http://www.houmatoday.com/article/20101231/ARTICLES/101239963|title=Nikki Buskey, Drive-in was social center for south Lafourche teens: One in a series on local landmarks and traditions that no longer exist, December 31, 2010|publisher=''Houma Today''|accessdate=October 3, 2013}} Guidry died at the age of eighty-four on March 26, 2014.Staff [http://www.houmatoday.com/article/20140326/HURBLOG/140329617/0/PREPS?p=1&tc=pg "Legendary Lafourche politician dies"], ''Houma Today,'' March 26, 2014. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Portalbar|Louisiana|Politics|Business and Economics}} {{s-start}} {{succession box |before=Dudley A. Bernard
Woolen J. Falgout |title=[[Louisiana State Legislature|Louisiana State Representative for Lafourche Parish]] Richard P. "Dick" Guidry |years=1964—1976 |after=L. G. LaPlante, Jr.}} {{s-end}} {{Louisiana Political Museum and Hall of Fame}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Guidry, Dick}} [[Category:1929 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:Members of the Louisiana House of Representatives]] [[Category:Louisiana Democrats]] [[Category:People from Galliano, Louisiana]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Louisiana]] [[Category:Cajun people]] [[Category:Place of death missing]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Douglas Schoen | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1953|6|27}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | nationality = United States | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education =[[Harvard College]], BA (magna cum laude), 1974
[[Harvard Law School]], [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]
[[Oxford University]], PhD | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | known_for = | notable_works = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | denomination = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | website = | footnotes = | influences = | influenced = | box_width = }} '''Douglas Schoen''' (born June 27, 1953) is a [[Jewish American]] [[political analyst]], author, lobbyist, and commentator. == Education == Schoen attended [[Horace Mann School]] in New York City.{{cite news |title=Who is Dick Morris? |date=August 7, 1995 |work=[[New York Magazine]] |pages=34 et seq. |accessdate=November 3, 2010 |first1=Jacob |last1=Weisberg |authorlink1=Jacob Weisberg |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ROMCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq=horace+mann+high+school+alumni+%2Bschoen&source=bl&ots=zQIAiE56Ai&sig=kBgdcTSFf5YQOH7kqvAmjvChY1s&hl=en&ei=tBnSTL2SL4GB8gay-vHeDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&sqi=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q&f=false |quote=Penn and Schoen are... city bred prodigies. The two attended Horace Mann together and became a political team at Harvard, where they worked on the ''Crimson''.... As pollsters, the Laurel and Hardy-ish pair are known for a hard quantitative bent.... But if Penn and Schoen are moderates....}} While still a high school student, he canvassed the [[Upper West Side]] for [[Dick Morris]].{{Cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,985538-3,00.html|title=MASTERS OF THE MESSAGE|last=Stengel|first=Richard|date=1996-11-18|last2=Pooley|first2=Eric|newspaper=Time|issn=0040-781X|access-date=2016-11-01}} He graduated from [[Harvard College]] (''[[magna cum laude]]'') and [[Harvard Law School]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=ROMCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA36&lpg=PA36&dq=horace+mann+high+school+alumni++schoen&source=bl&ots=zQIAiE56Ai&sig=kBgdcTSFf5YQOH7kqvAmjvChY1s&hl=en&ei=tBnSTL2SL4GB8gay-vHeDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&sqi=2&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=New York Magazine|last=LLC|first=New York Media|date=1995-08-07|publisher=New York Media, LLC|language=en}}{{cite web |title=About Doug |accessdate=November 3, 2010 |url=http://www.powerofthevote.com/about_doug_schoen.php}} Schoen went to high school with [[Mark Penn]] and then worked together with him on ''[[The Harvard Crimson]]''. == Career == Schoen currently serves on the Advisory Council of [[Represent.Us]], a [[Nonpartisanism|nonpartisan]] anti-corruption organization.{{Cite news|url=http://represent.us/about|title=About {{!}} Represent.Us|newspaper=End corruption. Defend the Republic.|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-02}} === Consulting work === While still at Harvard, Schoen first worked as an independent political consultant for [[Louis Gigante]], who ran for [[New York City Council]] in 1973.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=OwQBDQAAQBAJ&pg=PA353&lpg=PA353&dq=douglas+schoen+fox+news+hired&source=bl&ots=AP_KFQeJJp&sig=xAITGNR9gujpjrZ9yDFUu095D10&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj53O6Z6IfQAhXhx4MKHTy1BF4Q6AEIUDAJ#v=onepage&q=douglas%20schoen%20fox%20news%20hired&f=false|title=Democracy for Hire: A History of American Political Consulting|last=Johnson|first=Dennis W.|date=2016-11-07|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190272692|language=en}} In 1977, he founded the political consulting firm [[Penn, Schoen & Berland]] with political strategists [[Mark Penn]]. [[Michael Berland]] joined the firm in 1987. Schoen worked for the political campaigns of politicians including [[Jay Rockefeller]], [[Richard Shelby]] and [[Evan Bayh]]. Following the 1994 [[United States elections, 1994|United States elections]], President [[Bill Clinton]] hired [[Dick Morris]], who brought on Schoen and Penn. Schoen worked on the 1996 campaign as well in survey analysis. Schoen also began doing corporate work beginning in the 1980s. In 2000, Ukrainian steel oligarch [[Victor Pinchuk]] hired Schoen on a $40,000 per month retainer. In 2004, Schoen introduced Pinchuk to [[Hillary Clinton]].{{cite news|last1=Chozick|first1=Amy|authorlink=Amy Chozick|title=Trade Dispute Centers on Ukrainian Executive With Ties to Clintons|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/13/us/politics/trade-dispute-centers-on-ukrainian-executive-with-ties-to-clintons.html|accessdate=11 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 February 2014|page=A19}} He also did work for the [[Hillary Clinton presidential campaign, 2008]] and later became associated with the [[People United Means Action]] movement of disaffected Clinton supporters who refused to support [[Barack Obama]].Steve Benen [http://www.salon.com/politics/war_room/2008/04/16/schoen/print.html Clinton pollster urges senator to go relentlessly negative] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625205924/http://www.salon.com/politics/war_room/2008/04/16/schoen/print.html |date=June 25, 2008 }} April 16, 2008 Salon.comGlenn Greenwald [http://www.salon.com/opinion/greenwald/2007/09/27/schoen/ Douglas Schoen and Hillary's slimy pollsters] September 27, 2008 Salon.com Schoen was a consultant for [[Jeff Greene]] in the [[United States Senate election in Florida, 2010|2010 Florida Senate election]].[http://www.politico.com/blogs/bensmith/0410/Dems_worry_about_a_subprime_billionaire_in_Florida.html Dems worry about a subprime billionaire (Jeff Greene) in Florida] April 28, 2010 The firm was sold to [[WPP plc]] in 2001. Schoen left the firm later to work for news media. In 2010, Schoen hosted a fundraiser for [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] congressional candidate [[John Gomez]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/07/douglas-schoen-fox-news-c_n_754643.html|title=Fox News 'Democratic Pollster' Fundraising For GOP|date=2010-10-07|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-11-01}} Pinchuk donated $13.1 million to the [[Clinton Foundation]] in the years after Schoen's introduction. In 2011, Schoen registered as a foreign agent lobbying on behalf of Pinchuk. Between September 2011 and November 2012, Schoen arranged nearly a dozen meetings between Pinchuk and senior State Department officials, including [[Melanne Verveer]]. In September 2015, Pinchuk donated $150,000 to the [[Donald J. Trump Foundation]] in exchange for a 20-minute video appearance by [[Donald Trump]] shown at a policy conference that year in Kiev.{{cite news|last1=Schmidt|first1=Michael S.|authorlink1=Michael S. Schmidt|last2=Haberman|first2=Maggie|authorlink2=Maggie Haberman|title=Mueller Investigating Ukrainian’s $150,000 Payment for a Trump Appearance|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/09/us/politics/trump-mueller-ukraine-victor-pinchuk.html|accessdate=11 April 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=10 April 2018|page=A1}} [[Michael Cohen (lawyer)|Michael Cohen]] solicited Schoen for the donation from Pinchuk, which was the largest outside donation the Trump Foundation received that year. In March 2017, former Trump aid [[Monica Crowley]] registered as a foreign agent working for Pinchuk under Schoen's direction.{{cite news|last1=Gramer|first1=Robbie|title=One-Time Trump National Security Pick Registers As Foreign Agent for Ukrainian Oligarch|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2017/03/14/trump-national-security-aide-registers-as-foreign-agent-for-ukrainian-oligarch-monica-crowley-plagiarism-scandal-victor-pinchuk-ukraine-billionaire/|accessdate=11 April 2018|work=[[Foreign Policy]]|date=14 March 2017|language=en}} === Media === Schoen became a political analyst for [[Fox News]] and a columnist for [[Newsmax]]. In 2010, he authored a book on the [[Tea Party movement]] with [[Scott Rasmussen]]. == Views == Schoen has identified as a member of the Democratic party, but has frequently criticized the party and taken positions on various political topics at odds with the party's views. Schoen's critics have called his identification as a Democrat "phony" and calculated to help his Fox news career.{{Cite news|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/politico44/2011/12/doug-schoen-democrat-108176|title=Doug Schoen: "Democrat"?|last=Thrush|first=Glenn|date=|work=|newspaper=POLITICO|access-date=2016-11-01|via=}} [[Steve Benen]] called Schoen the quintessential "Fox News Democrat" and said he is "actively hostile towards [Democrats] and the party’s agenda."{{Cite web|url=http://washingtonmonthly.com/2011/10/18/doug-schoen-isnt-helping-his-reputation/|title=Doug Schoen isn’t helping his reputation|last=Benen|first=Steve|date=2011-10-18|website=Washington Monthly|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-01}} Schoen says that lower taxes would be a successful Democratic strategy, opposed President [[Barack Obama]]'s [[Affordable Care Act]], and said that President Obama should not run for reelection in [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012]]. He has stated that President Obama divided the country along partisan lines, and said that the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]] has been a "disaster" for the Democratic Party.[http://www.politico.com/news/stories/1011/66228.html Schoen warns W.H.: Don't back 'Occupy'] By MJ Lee, Politico, October 18, 2011[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/11/12/AR2010111202846.html Opinion | One and done: To be a great president, Obama should not seek reelection in 2012] By Douglas E. Schoen and Patrick H. Caddell, November 14, 2010 Schoen has been critical of the [[Occupy Wall Street]] protest movement. In a ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' [[op-ed]], he wrote, "President Obama and the Democratic leadership are making a critical error in embracing the Occupy Wall Street movement—and it may cost them the 2012 election."[https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204479504576637082965745362 Polling the Occupy Wall Street Crowd: In interviews, protesters show that they are leftists out of step with most American voters. Yet Democrats are embracing them anyway.] By DOUGLAS SCHOEN, Wall Street Journal, October 18, 2011 He believes that the protesters represent "an unrepresentative segment of the electorate that believes in radical redistribution of wealth, civil disobedience and, in some instances, violence," and that their common bond is "a deep commitment to left-wing policies." Schoen believes that the Democratic Party should not appeal to voters who support taxing oil companies and the rich, but rather to voters in the middle who want lower taxes.[http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/culture/2011/10/3790409/survey-many-occupy-wall-street-protesters-are-unhappy-democrats-who- Survey: Many Occupy Wall Street protesters are unhappy Democrats who want more influence] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111019172239/http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/culture/2011/10/3790409/survey-many-occupy-wall-street-protesters-are-unhappy-democrats-who- |date=October 19, 2011 }}, By Azi Paybarah, Capital New York, October 18, 2011[http://thinkprogress.org/politics/2011/10/18/347165/breaking-doug-schoen-grossly-misrepresents-his-own-poll-results-to-smear-occupy-wall-street/ Doug Schoen Grossly Misrepresents His Own Poll Results To Smear Occupy Wall Street] By Judd Legum, Think Progress,Oct 18, 2011{{cite web|last=Benen|first=Steve|title=Doug Schoen isn't helping his reputation|url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/political-animal/2011_10/doug_schoen_isnt_helping_his_r032892.php#|work=Political Animal blog|publisher=Washington Monthly|accessdate=October 19, 2011}} On October 30, 2016, Schoen pulled his support of Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, citing his concern of a "constitutional crisis" due to Secretary Clinton's email scandal if elected. ==Works== *''Declaring independence: the beginning of the end of the two-party system'', New York: Random House, 2008, {{ISBN|9781400067336}}, {{OCLC|173683636}} *''The threat closer to home: Hugo Chávez and the war against America'', New York: Free Press, 2009, {{ISBN|9781416594772}}, {{OCLC|213839994}} *''Hopelessly divided : the new crisis in American politics and what it means for 2012 and beyond'', Lanham, Md.: Rowman & Littlefield Publishers, 2012, {{ISBN|9781442215238}}, {{OCLC|759173285}} *''The Nixon effect: how Richard Nixon's presidency fundamentally changed American politics'', New York; London: Encounter Books, 2016, {{ISBN|9781594037993}}, {{OCLC|891619019}} *''America in the age of Trump: opportunities and oppositions in an unsettled world'', New York: Encounter Books, 2017, {{ISBN|9781594039478}}, {{OCLC|969830291}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{C-SPAN|Douglas Schoen}} {{Fox News personalities}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schoen, Douglas}}
