revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians --> | name = Kat Bjelland | image = Kat Bjelland 2015.png | caption = Bjelland performing at [[Primavera Sound]] with [[Babes in Toyland (band)|Babes in Toyland]], 2015 | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Katherine Lynne Bjelland | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1963|12|9}} |birth_place = [[Salem, Oregon|Salem]], [[Oregon]], U.S. | death_date = | origin = | instrument ={{hlist|Vocals|guitar|bass|piano}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Alternative rock]]|[[punk rock]]}} | occupation = {{hlist|Musician|singer|songwriter}} | years_active = 1982–present | label = {{hlist|Doomedelic| Treehouse| [[Twin Tone Records|Twin Tone]]| [[Southern Records|Southern]]|[[Reprise Records|Reprise]]| [[Sympathy for the Record Industry]]|[[Integrity Records|Integrity]]|Rish}} | associated_acts = {{hlist|The Venarays| [[Sugar Babydoll]]| [[Pagan Babies (band)|Pagan Babies]]|Italian Whorenuns| [[Babes in Toyland (band)|Babes in Toyland]]| [[Hole (band)|Hole]]|[[Melvins]]| [[Lubricated Goat]]| [[Crunt]]| [[Katastrophy Wife]]}} | website = }}
'''Katherine Lynne "Kat" Bjelland''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|j|ɛ|l|ə|n|d}}<ref name=nyt/> (born December 9, 1963) is an American singer, songwriter, musician and guitarist. Bjelland rose to prominence as the lead singer, guitarist, and songwriter of the [[alternative rock]] band [[Babes in Toyland (band)|Babes in Toyland]], which she formed in [[Minneapolis]], Minnesota in 1987.
Born in [[Salem, Oregon]], Bjelland was raised in nearby [[Woodburn, Oregon|Woodburn]], and learned to play guitar as a teenager from her uncle, with whom she performed in his band shortly after graduating high school. Upon dropping out of college at age nineteen, she relocated to [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], where she became involved in the city's music scene; there, she met [[Courtney Love]] and the two became friends, forming the band [[Pagan Babies (band)|Pagan Babies]].
After the dissolution of Pagan Babies in 1985, Bejalland relocated to Minneapolis, where she formed Babes in Toyland with drummer [[Lori Barbero]]. The band's debut record, ''[[Spanking Machine]]'', was released in 1990, after which they toured Europe with [[Sonic Youth]]. This was followed by their second album, ''[[Fontanelle (album)|Fontanelle]]'' (1992). The band would release their third studio album, ''[[Nemesisters]]'', in 1995. In the mid-late 1990s, Bjelland collaborated on other musical projects, including contributing as a bassist in the band [[Crunt]] with her then-husband, Australian musician [[Stu Spasm|Stuart Gray]].
Babes in Toyland formally disbanded in 2001, and Bjelland began working with [[Katastrophy Wife]], a project under which she released the albums ''[[Amusia (album)|Amusia]]'' (2001) and ''[[All Kneel]]'' (2004). She remained out of the public light after being diagnosed with [[schizoaffective disorder]] in 2007, but in 2015, reunited with Babes in Toyland and began touring internationally.
==Early life== Bjelland was born on December 9, 1963{{sfn|Larkin|2000|p=28}} in [[Salem, Oregon]]{{sfn|Escamilla|1996|p=7}} to Lynne Irene (née Higginbotham) and Lyle Bjelland. She was raised in [[Woodburn, Oregon|Woodburn]], a small town north of Salem. "It's predominantly [[Russian Orthodox Church|Orthodox Russians]] and [[Hispanic]]s," Bjelland said of the community, "So being [[white people|white]] [was] more like being a minority... We lived at the edge of town, so there was complete wilderness behind us."<ref name=peel>{{cite interview|last=Bjelland|first=Kat|interviewer=[[John Peel]]|title=Kat Bjelland interview|publisher=[[BBC Radio One]]|date=August 28, 1993|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RWgk642A67o&t=329s}}</ref>
When Bjelland was five years old, her mother abandoned their family.{{sfn|Karlen|1994|p=2}} Bjelland's father subsequently remarried, after which she claimed to have been physically and verbally abused by her stepmother.<ref name=spanks/><ref name=notbad/> "You know, I really hate to talk about it because she's great now, but in my childhood she was very abusive," she said. "It probably did help my creativity a lot [though]. I was always [[Grounding (discipline technique)|grounded]]. I hate to talk about it because I feel like she doesn't think that she did it, but she was [abusive] and it influenced my life quite a great deal."<ref name="notbad" />
Bjelland became interested in music as a young child, and began listening to rock and roll records.<ref name=nyt/> As an adolescent, she became enamored with [[Rush (band)|Rush]], and attended four of their concerts.<ref name=peel/> She also cited [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]], [[Cheap Trick]], [[The B-52's]], the [[Plasmatics]], and [[Captain Beefheart]] among her favorite artists while growing up.<ref name=peel/> Her uncle, David Higginbotham, taught Bjelland to play guitar in her youth. Her first performance was at a small bar in Woodburn called Flight 99 (now defunct), playing with her uncle in a band called The Neurotics.<ref name=nyt>{{Cite web|title=Pop/Jazz; Post-Punk Angst of Babes in Toyland|work=The New York Times|date= March 27, 1992|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/03/27/arts/pop-jazz-post-punk-angst-of-babes-in-toyland.html|accessdate=November 4, 2017|author=Schoemer, Karen|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101207170056/https://www.nytimes.com/1992/03/27/arts/pop-jazz-post-punk-angst-of-babes-in-toyland.html|archivedate=December 7, 2010|deadurl=no}} {{closed access}}</ref><ref name=current>{{cite web|url=https://blog.thecurrent.org/2013/03/kat-bjelland-on-babes-and-toyland-and-her-long-and-winding-musical-path/|work=The Current|title=Babes in Toyland|accessdate=November 4, 2017|date=March 10, 2013|author=Swensson, Karen}}</ref><ref name=lore>{{cite web|url=http://www.portlandmercury.com/portland/return-to-toyland/Content?oid=16398284|work=Portland Mercury|title=Return to Toyland|accessdate=November 4, 2017|author=Lore, Mark|date=September 2, 2015}}</ref>
She attended [[Woodburn High School]], where she played on the school basketball team and was a cheerleader.<ref name=nbk>{{cite AV media notes|title=Natural Babe Killers| titlelink =Natural Babe Killers| others =Babes in Toyland| year = July 11, 2000| chapter =| first = Burrows| last = Brian| page = 2| type = CD booklet| publisher = Snapper Music| location = United Kingdom}}</ref>{{sfn|Gaar|2002|p=388}} After graduating from high school in 1982, Bjelland briefly enrolled at the [[University of Oregon]], but dropped out after her freshman year and relocated to [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] at age nineteen.{{sfn|Gaar|2002|p=389}} During this time, Bjelland worked as a [[stripper]] to support herself.{{Sfn|Gaar|2002|p=389}} She became introduced to [[punk rock|punk music]] after attending a [[Wipers]] concert in Portland: "I didn't know about punk rock that much," she recalled. "I was from a small town. All of a sudden I was like, 'What the fuck is this?'"<ref name=woodward/>
==Career== ===1982–86: Early projects=== At age nineteen, Bjelland purchased her first guitar, a [[Rickenbacker|Rickenbacker 425]], from a [[pawn shop]] for $200.<ref name=nbk/> In Portland, she formed a series of bands, first The Neurotics and then an all-female band called The Venarays, which Bjelland has described as "rock with a '60s edge." The Neurotics were composed of Bjelland (rhythm guitar); her uncle David Higginbotham (lead guitar); Marty Wyman (vocals); Brian McMillan (drums); and Laura Robertson (bass).<ref name=nyt/> Commenting on the band, Bjelland said: "After The Neurotics I got this band together with my best friends, so it was an all-girl band. We were called The Venarays. The name came from the word ''venary'' which means ''actively hunting out sex''! We began as a way of having fun with each other."{{sfn|Evans|1994|p=64}} In reality, the Venarays was not an all-girl band as drummer Dave Hummel, and later, Jack Rhodes, were men. The name 'Venarays' was taken from a television character called Vena Ray in an early 1950s program called Rocky Jones Space Ranger. After the band was named, some members of the band discovered the word 'venary' in the dictionary and became confused regarding the origin.
After quitting The Venarays, Bjelland met [[Courtney Love]] in 1984 at the [[Satyricon (nightclub)|Satyricon]], a Portland nightclub, and the two started a band called [[Sugar Babydoll]].{{sfn|St. Thomas|Smith|2004|p=97}} The two relocated to [[San Francisco]] in 1985, after which they were joined in the group by drummer Suzanne Ramsey,{{sfn|Baldwin|2004|p=97}} and bassist [[Jennifer Finch]].{{sfn|Brite|1998|p=79}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.papermag.com/the-15-grungiest-grunge-artists-a-power-ranking-1427419902.html|work=Paper Magazine|title=The 15 Grungiest Grunge Artists: A Power Ranking|date=September 24, 2014|accessdate=December 5, 2016}}</ref> Bjelland recalled: "We went through a few names, and we only played a couple of shows. It was the smallest thing I've ever done musically."{{sfn|Evans|1994|p=66}} After Finch left the group, they renamed themselves the Pagan Babies and introduced Deirdre Schletter and [[Janis Tanaka]], releasing a four-track demo in December 1985 before disbanding. Love went on to form the band [[Hole (band)|Hole]] in 1989, while Finch would be part of [[L7 (band)|L7]].<ref>{{cite episode|people=Bjelland, Kat, et al.|series=[[E! True Hollywood Story]]|title=Courtney Love|network= E! Networks|airdate=October 5, 2003|season=7|number=32}}</ref>
===1987–2001: Babes in Toyland=== {{Main|Babes in Toyland (band)}} [[File:Babes In Toyland Paris 1991.jpg|thumb|left|upright=1|Bjelland performing with Babes in Toyland in [[Paris]], 1991]] In the mid-1980s, Bjelland moved from [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]] to [[Minneapolis]], where she formed [[Babes in Toyland (band)|Babes in Toyland]]. She met [[Lori Barbero]] at a barbecue not long after moving to Minneapolis in the mid-1980s, and convinced her to become a drummer – something that Lori became talented at. The pair joined with bassist Michelle Leon, and Babes in Toyland was formed. Bjelland has said she intentionally sought out bandmates who had no instrumental experience: "Lori didn't know how to play when I met her. Michelle didn't know how to play. I was self-taught. Hopefully, from being technically inexperienced, you can use your imagination, and play the drums like an instrument instead of just being a beat-keeper. And play the bass like you feel it, from your gut, instead of saying, 'Here's my scales.'"<ref name=nyt/>
The band recorded their first extended play, ''[[To Mother]]'', in London in 1990, titled in honor of Bjelland's mother, whom she had discovered died of [[pancreatic cancer]] on the first day of the recording sessions.{{sfn|Leon|2016|p=110}} After signing to [[Reprise Records]] in 1991,{{sfn|Gaar|2002|p=390}} Babes in Toyland's debut single, "Dust Cake Boy" [[b-side|b/w]] "Spit to See the Shine" was well-received. After touring Europe with [[Sonic Youth]], the band recorded their debut album ''[[Spanking Machine]]'', which also was well- received, and was compared to the music of [[The Birthday Party (band)|The Birthday Party]] and [[New York Dolls]].<ref name="spanks">{{cite journal|work=Melody Maker|date=September 22, 1990|author=True, Everett|title=Spanks for the memory}}</ref> The group would become misidentified as part of the [[riot grrrl]] movement, though Bjelland has denied having anything to do with the movement, which emphasized [[feminism|female domination]]. As she said in a 1992 interview: "I don't feel helpless or anything. I don't feel like I have to be like, "I'm a female and I can do this if I want to", cause, of course I can. I already know that, and I never felt being female hurt anything. If anything, it helped."<ref name=notbad>{{cite av media|people=Rose, Lisa Apriam (dir.)|title=Not Bad for a Girl|year=1995|publisher=Horizon Unlimited|format=VHS}}</ref>
[[File:Samuel_Payne_and_Kat_Bjelland_Taking_Tea_on_the_Cupola_House_Roof.jpg|right|thumb|upright=1|Bjelland in Minneapolis, circa 1992]] In 1991, the band toured in Europe with [[Sonic Youth]], which was documented in the film ''[[1991: The Year Punk Broke]]''.<ref>{{cite web|work=Variety|url=https://variety.com/1992/film/reviews/1991-the-year-punk-broke-1200431076/|title=1991: The Year Punk Broke|author=Harvey, Dennis|date=December 2, 1992|accessdate=May 10, 2018}}</ref> Following this, Babes in Toyland peaked in commercial success when they performed on a portion of the [[Lollapalooza]] tour in 1993,<ref>{{cite web|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/feb/03/cult-heroes-babes-in-toylands-kat-bjelland-overlooked-90s-punk-powerhouse|title=Cult heroes: Babes in Toyland's Kat Bjelland – overlooked 90s punk powerhouse|author=Andrews, Charlotte Richardson|date=February 3, 2015|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref> and released their second album, ''[[Fontanelle (album)|Fontanelle]]'' (1992), which sold over 250,000 copies.{{sfn|Earles|2014|p=23}} In 1994, the band was featured on the covers of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' and ''[[USA Today]]''.<ref>{{cite web|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/08/28/arts/pop-music-the-return-of-the-punk-girl-native.html|title=The Return of the Punk Girl Native|date=August 28, 1994|accessdate=November 4, 2017|author=Karlen, Neal}}</ref>
In 1993, Bjelland moved to Seattle and began a side project called [[Crunt]] with her then-husband, Australian musician [[Stu Spasm|Stuart Gray]] (also known as Stu Spasm),{{sfn|Evans|1994|p=73}} formerly of [[Lubricated Goat]].<ref name="current"/> Bjelland played bass and Gray guitar, while Russell Simins of [[Jon Spencer Blues Explosion]] was the drummer.<ref>{{cite journal|work=[[Maximumrocknroll]]|title=Interview with Crunt|year=1993|pages=50–51|issue=127}}</ref> In February 1994, the band released a self-titled debut, along with its first single, "Swine". During this time, Bjelland also co-wrote the track "I Think That I Would Die" on Hole's breakthrough album ''[[Live Through This]]'' (1994) with Courtney Love and guitarist [[Eric Erlandson]].<ref>Liner notes of ''Live Through This'' (1994) by Geffen Records/DGC.</ref>
In January 1995, Bjelland and Gray divorced and Crunt disbanded;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/crunt-mn0002155375|work=AllMusic|title=Crunt – Music Biography|accessdate=July 22, 2012}}</ref> Bjelland turned her focus back to Babes in Toyland, and the group released their third and final full-length album, ''[[Nemesisters]]'' in 1995. After this, she moved to [[Brooklyn]], New York,<ref name="current" /> and contributed to the 1997 album ''Songs of the [[Witchblade]]: A Soundtrack to the Comic Book'', for the [[Top Cow]]'s comics of the same name. She composed, played and produced most of songs, with many rock and metal artists like [[Megadeth]] or [[Peter Steele]] ([[Type O Negative]]), and also collaborated with a freeform musical project called Last Frenzy in [[England]].<ref name=key/> Babes in Toyland maintained a loyal following throughout the rest of the decade, and in November 2001, played a farewell show in Minneapolis.<ref>{{cite web|work=Rolling Stone|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/live-reviews/babes-in-toyland-return-as-ferocious-as-ever-at-l-a-comeback-show-20150213|title=Babes in Toyland Return as Ferocious as Ever at L.A. Comeback Show |accessdate=May 9, 2018|date=February 13, 2015|author=Fonarow, Wendy}}</ref>
===2002–2014: Katastrophy Wife=== With Babes in Toyland playing only performing sporadically in the late 1990s, Bjelland started the band Katastrophy Wife in 1998 as a side project with her then-husband, drummer Adrian Johnson.<ref name=diskat>{{cite web|work=[[Drowned in Sound]]|title=Katastrophy Wife Biography|accessdate=December 30, 2017|url=http://drownedinsound.com/artists/Katastrophy_Wife|archivedate=March 24, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160324105617/http://drownedinsound.com/artists/Katastrophy_Wife|deadurl=no}}</ref> The band toured at venues, such as [[Ladyfest]], worldwide, and released two albums, ''[[Amusia (album)|Amusia]]'' (2001) and ''[[All Kneel]]'' (2004). Tom Edwards of ''[[Drowned in Sound]]'' gave ''All Kneel'' a favorable review, ranking it among Bjelland's best work.<ref>{{cite web|work=[[Drowned in Sound]]|url=http://drownedinsound.com/releases/3710/reviews/9720-|title=Album Review: Katastrophy Wife: All Kneel|author=Edwards, Tom|date=May 30, 2004|accessdate=May 11, 2018}}</ref>
The band released a vinyl and CD single, ''Heart On'', on the Australian record label Rish in April 2007.<ref>{{cite av media|people=Katastrophy Wife|title=Heart On|format=CD single|year=2007|id= RiSHV01|publisher=Rish Records}}</ref> The single was intended as a trailer for a forthcoming album, ''Pregnant.'' Katstrophy Wife's vinyl debut was on an Independent label compilation called ''The Tundra Sessions'', featuring production by Tim Mac.<ref name=faster>{{cite web|url=http://www.fasterlouder.com.au/features/8900/Katastrophy_Wifes_Kat_Bjelland_gets_her_HeartOn|work=FasterLouder|title=Katastrophy Wife's KatBjelland gets her Heart-On|accessdate=November 4, 2017|author=Bann, Chantel|date=May 3, 2007}}</ref> although as of 2011 the album has not been released. Bjelland also produced and contributed guest vocals on the album ''[[The Seven Year Itch (Angelica album)|The Seven Year Itch]]'' for the band [[Angelica (band)|Angelica]], released in 2002.<ref>{{cite web|work=AllMusic|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-seven-year-itch-mw0000227042/credits|title=The Seven Year Itch - Angelica - Credits|accessdate=May 11, 2018}}</ref>
In 2006, on the official Katastrophy Wife website, Bjelland wrote that "Katastrophy Wife have had a few incarnations but from here on I will only re-incarnate my self."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://katastrophywife.com/kat.html|work=Katastrophywife.com|accessdate=May 10, 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060618114408/http://www.katastrophywife.com/kat.html|archivedate=June 18, 2006|title=Ordeals and Schpiels of the Catastrophe Wife}}</ref> The following year, in 2007, she was diagnosed with a [[schizoaffective disorder]] and institutionalized for a period, and remained out of the public light for several years.<ref name=woodward/>
===2015–present: Babes in Toyland reunion=== In 2014, Bjelland reunited with former bandmates [[Maureen Herman]] and Lori Barbero and began rehearsing to perform live shows.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/video/babes-in-toyland-reunite-18-years-later-can-they-take-us-by-storm-again-42133803|title=Babes in Toyland Reunite 18 Years Later: Can They Take Us By Storm Again?|author=Hkam, Hso|date=February 10, 2015|accessdate=February 12, 2015|work=LA Weekly}}</ref> "People would show me on the Internet all these young fans who wanted to see us, and I felt kind of obligated to play," said Bjelland. "You see people with their moms and even grandmothers coming to the shows together. It's super cool. I'm just surprised at how much people still like it."<ref name=nashville/>
In February 2015, the band played their first live show together in fourteen years in [[Joshua Tree, California]], and performed additional shows on an international tour throughout 2015.<ref name=nashville/><ref name=woodward>{{cite web|work=[[Gambit (newspaper)|Gambit]]|url=https://www.bestofneworleans.com/gambit/babes-in-toyland/Content?oid=2796174|date=October 27, 2015|title=Interview: Babes in Toyland's Kat Bjelland on the band's second coming |author=Woodward, Alex|accessdate=May 11, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105015638/http://www.bestofneworleans.com/gambit/babes-in-toyland/Content?oid=2796174|archivedate=January 5, 2017}}</ref> Bjelland commented that she intended to write new material, but that it would be concerned with "less anger about people. Now it's about things that are going on in the world. I've got a whole plethora of songs ready to go."<ref name=nashville/>
==Musical style== ===Influences=== As a child, Bjelland's favorite band was [[Rush (band)|Rush]], particularly their fourth album ''[[2112 (album)|2112]]''.<ref name=peel/> "It was kind of a band that girls didn't like, just guys liked them... I liked them because they had weird, spacey other-land lyrics, and lots of [[break (music)|break]]s, and really cool instrumentation," she said.<ref name=peel/> As an adolescent, she also listened to popular rock bands such as [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]] and [[Cheap Trick]].<ref name=peel/> She would later credit [[Cocteau Twins]], [[The Miracle Workers]], and the [[Wipers]] as early influences,<ref name="current"/> and also said she listened to [[Billie Holiday]] as a teenager.{{sfn|Gaar|2002|p=388}} As an adult, Bjelland named [[Captain Beefheart]], [[Charles Mingus]], [[Leonard Cohen]], [[Frightwig]], [[Girlschool]], [[Motörhead]],<ref name=woodward/> and other '70s metal bands as important to her.<ref name="current"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/kat-bjelland-of-babes-in-toyland-19950518|work=Rolling Stone|date=May 18, 1995|accessdate=October 30, 2017|title=Q&A: Kat Bjelland of Babes in Toyland|author=Mundy, Chris}}</ref>
===Voice and instrumentation=== [[File:Dave higginbotham by andrew parodi.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Bjelland learned to play guitar from her uncle, David Higginbotham (pictured), a local musician<ref name=nyt/>]] Bjelland has been noted by music critics for her unique screaming vocals,<ref name=nyt/> which have been likened to those of [[Ozzy Osbourne]] and [[Diamanda Galás]].<ref>{{cite web|work=The Independent|title=Grace's grisly grunt and grind show|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/rock-graces-grisly-grunt-and-grind-show-1554016.html|date=September 26, 1992|author=Thompson, Ben|accessdate=May 17, 2018}}</ref> Journalist Richard Cromelin noted in a 1992 ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' profile that "She retches her enraged lyrics, her screams skid across the beat and collide with the blunt riffs. Her voice erupts into laughs and gargles, then croons down low with eerie detachment."<ref name=lat>{{cite web|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1992-11-15/entertainment/ca-623_1_guitarist-kat-bjelland|title=Year of the Kat : Kat Bjelland's penchant for purging her emotions brings Babes in Toyland to the brink of alternative rock stardom|date=November 25, 1992|accessdate=October 30, 2017|author=Cromelin, Richard}}</ref>
Commenting on her musical aspirations, Bjelland said: "It should sound like nothing that you've heard before. That's my intention... Like my singing, all I try to do is I just push myself into things where I think I can't reach notes and stuff. Sometimes it sounds really ridiculous, but then you just kind of work on it."<ref name=lat/> A 2015 concert review described her voice as one so powerful that it "can strip the chrome off a bumper."<ref>{{cite web|work=Chicago Reader|url=https://www.chicagoreader.com/Bleader/archives/2015/09/13/day-two-of-riot-fest-bootsy-collins-alien-jizz-and-senior-citizens-kicking-everyones-asses|date=September 13, 2015|title=Day two of Riot Fest: Bootsy Collins, alien jizz, and senior citizens kicking everyone's asses|author=''Reader'' staff|accessdate=May 9, 2018}}</ref>
In Babes in Toyland, Bjelland's instrumentation and songwriting has been described as "ugly, crunching [[post-punk]]," supplemented by "rudimentary" guitar chords.<ref name=nyt/> She learned to play guitar from her uncle, David Higgenbotham, with whom she played in his band, The Neurotics, prior to forming Babes in Toyland.<ref name=current/><ref name=lore/> Commenting on her guitar playing, Bjelland said: "I think it's not the quantity but the quality, and I don't think it's the speed you play, it's the soul that comes out."<ref name=peel/> In an interview with [[John Peel]], she reveled that she had never played with an [[effects unit|effects pedal]] until 1993: "If you learn how to play without effects, you have to learn how to make your guitar speak instead of the electronics."<ref name=peel/>
==Personal life== Bjelland was married to Australian musician [[Stu Spasm|Stuart Gray]] from 1992 to 1994,{{sfn|Escamilla|1996|p=7}} and later to drummer Adrian Johnson.<ref name=key/> She has one son, Henry, born {{circa}} 1999,<ref name=key>{{cite web|url=http://thekey.xpn.org/2015/10/22/babes-in-toyland/|work=The Key|location=Philadelphia|title=Babes in Toyland Rides Again: The 90s punk icons' road to reunion|date=October 22, 2015|author=Vettese, John|accessdate=May 10, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170617192915/http://thekey.xpn.org:80/2015/10/22/babes-in-toyland/|archivedate=June 17, 2017}}</ref> with Johnson. Bjelland has suffered with mental health issues and substance abuse problems throughout her life,<ref name=nashville/> and claimed to have had a [[nervous breakdown]] after the death of [[Kurt Cobain]] in 1994: "[I was in Seattle after he died] to hang out with Courtney and support her. In the funeral home, I saw him dead, which was more than disturbing... I had a nervous breakdown right after that."{{sfn|Yarm|2011|p=459}} During her original tenure with Babes in Toyland, Bjelland began using [[heroin]], though she denied using it regularly while touring.{{sfn|Yarm|2011|p=424}} "Let me make this clear: I never really did heroin on tour," she said in 2011.{{sfn|Yarm|2011|p=424}} "When I came home and was bored and depressed [and] with money, yeah, that's when I would do it. In my whole career on tour, I'm thinkin', I did it maybe three times."{{sfn|Yarm|2011|p=424}} To kick her habit prior to going on tours, Bjelland would [[binge drinking|binge drink]] through withdrawal symptoms.{{sfn|Yarm|2011|pages=424–25}}
In 2007, Bjelland suffered a [[schizophrenia|schizophrenic]] episode for which she was institutionalized.<ref name="faster"/><ref name=nashville>{{cite web|work=[[Nashville Scene]]|url=https://www.nashvillescene.com/music/article/13061853/the-altrock-reunion-boom-brings-babes-in-toyland-to-nashville|title=The alt-rock reunion boom brings Babes in Toyland to Nashville|author=Graves, Seth|date=October 29, 2015|accessdate=May 11, 2018}}</ref> She commented on the event, saying: "I don't know how I've progressed musically as such but a major influence in my writing was dealing with my whole schizophrenia episode. I actually haven't spoken to anyone much about this. Dealing with [[Dissociative identity disorder|multiple personalities]] was extremely difficult because some days I didn't know who I was or where I was at. I was very lucky that Adrian stuck by and helped me through it all. So obviously that was going to affect some of what I wrote about."<ref name="faster" /> She was later diagnosed with [[schizoaffective disorder]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/inside-babes-in-toylands-unlikely-reunion-20141118|author=Yarm, Mark|title=Babes in Toyland Reunite, With a Little Help From a Tech LLC|date=November 18, 2014|website=Rolling Stone|access-date=May 6, 2016}}</ref>
Bjelland has referred to former bandmate [[Courtney Love]] as her "soul sister," commenting in a 2001 interview: "I haven't spoken to Courtney for years but soul sisters don't need to. There will always be a bond between us, regardless of whether we speak or not."<ref name=miles/> In the 1990s, Bjelland and Love were often pitted against one another as rivals in media, with frequent comparisons between the two's visual appearances,{{sfn|Yarm|2011|p=353}} and had a falling out after Bjelland told a reporter: "Only about a quarter of what Courtney says is true. But nobody usually bothers to decipher which are the lies. She's all about image."<ref name=miles>{{cite news|url=https://www.thefreelibrary.com/WHY+KAT%27S+WILD+ABOUT+BRUM%3B+Courtney+Love%27s+soul+sister+is+cooling...-a076397860|via=The Free Library|title=WHY KAT'S WILD ABOUT BRUM; Courtney Love's soul sister is cooling down|accessdate=May 9, 2018|date=2001|author=Miles, Lucy|work=Birmingham Post & Mail}} {{free access}}</ref> Babes in Toyland's original bassist, Michelle Leon, claimed the rivalry between Love and Bjelland was "blown totally out of proportion," while Bjelland added in a 2011 interview: "The media did that, and it was really hurtful to me for a long time. They'd say it's some kind of battle. Which it wasn't. We were friends."{{sfn|Yarm|2011|p=353}} Bjelland participated in the ''[[Behind the Music]]'' segment on Love in 2010.<ref name="vh1">{{cite episode|network=[[VH1]]|airdate=June 21, 2010|title=Courtney Love|series=[[Behind the Music]]|publisher=Viacom Media Networks}}</ref>
==Discography== '''Babes in Toyland''' {{Main|Babes in Toyland discography}} * ''[[Spanking Machine]]'' (1990) *''[[Fontanelle (album)|Fontanelle]]'' (1992) *''[[Nemesisters]]'' (1995)
'''Crunt''' * ''[[Crunt (album)|Crunt]]'' (1994)
'''Katastrophy Wife''' * ''[[Amusia (album)|Amusia]]'' (2001) * ''[[All Kneel]]'' (2004)
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Works cited== *{{cite book|last=Baldwin|first=Michelle|year=2004|title=Burlesque and the New Bump-n-grind|publisher=Speck Press|isbn=978-0-972-57762-5|ref=harv|oclc= 711855821}} * {{cite book|last=Brite|first=Poppy Z. |author-link=Poppy Z. Brite|publisher=Simon & Schuster|title=[[Courtney Love: The Real Story]]|isbn=978-0-684-84800-6|year=1998|ref=harv|oclc=37392936}} *{{cite book|last=Earles|first=Andrew|year=2014|title=Gimme Indie Rock|publisher=Voyageur Press|ref=harv|isbn=978-1-627-88379-5|oclc= 891651577}} *{{cite book|last=Escamilla|first=Brian|title=Contemporary Musicians|publisher=Gale Research, Inc.|isbn=978-0-810-39317-2|year=1996|ref=harv|oclc=704003291}} *{{cite book|last=Evans|first=Liz|title=Women, Sex and Rock'n'roll: In Their Own Words|year=1994|publisher=Pandora|isbn=978-0-044-40900-7|oclc=494693178|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Gaar|first= Gillian G.|title=She's a Rebel: The History of Women in Rock and Roll|publisher=Seal Press|year=2002|isbn=978-1-580-05078-4|edition=2nd|ref=harv|oclc=495287089|orig-year=1992}} *{{cite book|last=Karlen|first=Neil|year=1994|title=Babes in Toyland: The Making and Selling of a Rock and Roll Band|publisher=Times Books|oclc= 936867546 |ref=harv|isbn=978-0-812-92058-1}} *{{cite book|last=Larkin|first=Colin|title=The Virgin Encyclopedia of Nineties Music|date=2000|publisher=Virgin Books|isbn=978-0-753-50427-7|ref=harv|oclc= 237407497}} *{{cite book|last=Leon|first=Michelle|year=2016|title=I Live Inside: Memoirs of a Babe in Toyland|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society|ref=harv|isbn=978-0-873-51999-1|oclc=922220168}} *{{cite book|title=Nirvana: The Chosen Rejects|last1=St. Thomas|first1= Kurt |last2=Smith|first2= Troy |publisher=St. Martin's Griffin/Macmillan Press|ref=harv|isbn=978-0-312-20663-5|year=2004|oclc= 41368230}} * {{cite book|last=Yarm|first=Mark|title=Everybody Loves Our Town: An Oral History of Grunge|isbn=978-0-307-46444-6|location=New York|publisher=Three Rivers Press|year=2011|ref=harv|oclc=935232799}}

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} [[File:Kathleen Lynn.jpg|thumb|Kathleen Lynn]] '''Kathleen Florence Lynn''' (28 January 1874 – 14 September 1955) was an Irish [[Sinn Féin]] politician, activist and medical doctor. She was born in Killala, Co Mayo, the daughter of a [[Church of Ireland]] rector. Lynn was so greatly affected by the poverty and disease among the poor in the west of Ireland that, at 16, she decided to be a doctor. She was educated in England and Germany, before enrolling in the Royal University of Ireland, a forerunner to the UCD School of Medicine. Following her graduation in 1899, Lynn went to the United States, where she worked for ten years, before returning to Ireland to become the first female doctor at the [[Royal Victoria Eye and Ear Hospital]] (1910–1916). In 1919, she founded [[Saint Ultan's Children's Hospital]]. ==Personal life== Kathleen Lynn was born on 28 January 1874 to a [[Church of Ireland]] clergyman, Robert Young Lynn, and his wife, Catherine Wynne,{{Cite web|url=https://civilrecords.irishgenealogy.ie/churchrecords/details-civil/753ba01490628|title=General Registrar's Office|last=|first=|date=|website=IrishGenealogy.ie|accessdate=28 January 2017}}{{Cite journal|last=Smyth|first=Hazel P.|date=1977-01-01|title=Kathleen Lynn, M.D., F.R.C.S.I. (1874-1955)|jstor=30087174|journal=Dublin Historical Record|volume=30|issue=2|pages=51–57}}{{Cite web|url=http://davidhicksbook.blogspot.gr/2016/03/mullafarry-rectory-killala-co.html|title=Mullafarry Rectory or Ballysakeery Glebe|last=|first=|date=26 March 2016|website=davidhicksbook.blogspot.gr|publisher=David Hicks|access-date=28 January 2017}} and was their second eldest child of their four children. Kathleen's older sister was called Anne Elizabeth and was born in 1873 with her younger sister Emily Muriel following behind Kathleen in 1876 to be followed by her younger brother and youngest sibling, John. Kathleen was born in the [[townland]] of Mullafarry, near [[Killala]] in [[County Mayo]].Ó, M., & Hogartaigh, M. O. (2006). Kathleen Lynn: Irishwoman, patriot, doctor. Dublin: Irish Academic Press. pp. 6 In 1882, the family moved to [[Shrule]] in County [[Longford]] where her father took over as the clergyman of the Ballymahon parish. Later on in her young life, in 1886 Kathleen and her family moved to Cong, a village bordering Mayo and Galway to where her father's parish was being funded by the [[Olivia Charlotte Guinness, Baroness Ardilaun|Lady Ardilaun]] of [[Ashford Castle]]. Kathleen was sent to the [[Alexandra College]], of which Lady Ardilaun was the patron, in Dublin which she attended till she was sixteen years old. She was distantly related to [[Countess Markievicz]] through her aunt's marriage.DOCUMENTARY ON KATHLEEN LYNN. (2008, Jun 21). Irish Times Retrieved from http://search.proquest.com/docview/309035631 Growing up in the aftermath of [[Great Famine (Ireland)|The Great Famine]] (1845 – 1852), Kathleen was deeply saddened by the deadly diseases and poverty suffered by the people in her local area. This led to her desire at sixteen, when she left school, to become a doctor.Kathleen Lynn: Insider on the outside, Art Exhibition, essay. (2016). Retrieved November 24, 2016, from http://www.kathleenlynn.net/essays/ Lynn's family didn't approve of her role in the rising. In fact, at the time, Lynn's family were so disgusted with her activities that they would not let her return home to Cong, Co.Mayo, for Christmas. She instead had to spend Christmas 1917 with her aunt Florence in Dublin. She did the same the following year, though she longed to spend Christmas with her family in Mayo. This personal split was eventually settled before her father's death in 1923.{{cite book|last1=Ó' hOgartaigh|first1=Margaret|title=Kathleen Lynn: Irishwoman, Patriot, Doctor|date=2006|publisher=Irish Academic Press|location=Dublin}} Lynn lived in [[Rathmines]] from 1903 to her death in 1955, sharing her home with her life partner [[Madeleine ffrench-Mullen]]. Lynn's diaries and letters provide an insight into this loving and long lived relationship. Lynn died on 14 September 1955, and is buried in the family plot at [[Deansgrange]] Cemetery. In acknowledgement of the role she played in the 1916 Rising and the [[Irish War of Independence]], she was buried with full military honours.Ó hÓgartaigh, Margaret, ''Kathleen Lynn. Irishwoman, Patriot, Doctor''. (Irish Academic Press, 2006). Lynn's personal diaries for the period 1916–1955, and the administrative papers of Saint Ultan's Hospital are held by the [[Royal College of Physicians of Ireland]] archive. ==Education== In 1891 Kathleen Lynn went as a boarder to [[Alexandra College]], [[Dublin]], from where she matriculated in 1893 from the [[Royal University of Ireland]]. From October 1897 Lynn took classes at the [[Catholic University of Ireland]]'s school of medicine in Cecilia Street, [[Dublin]], and in the [[Royal College of Surgeons of Ireland]]. In 1898 she won the Barker anatomical prize awarded by the college. She graduated MB BCh BAO from the [[Royal University of Ireland]] in 1899. Lynn conducted her internships at HollesStreet Hospital (1897–9), the [[Rotunda Hospital]] (1899), the [[Royal Victoria Eye and Ear Hospital]] (1899), and at the Richmond Lunatic Asylum. In 1898 Lynn was appointed the first woman resident doctor at [[Dublin]]'s [[Adelaide Hospital (Dublin)|Adelaide Hospital]], but staff opposition to her appointment meant she did not take up the post. She completed postgraduate work in the [[United States]] in the early 1900s before working as a duty doctor at hospitals in the city of [[Dublin]] as part of her wider general practice based at her home at 9 Belgrave Road, [[Rathmines]], [[Dublin]]. Lynn became a fellow of the [[Royal College of Physicians of Ireland]] in 1909, and was promoted to clinical assistant in the [[Royal Victoria Eye and Ear Hospital]] in the same year.{{cite web|title=Lynn, Kathleen (1874–1955), physician and political activist|url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/57724|website=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography|publisher=Maria Luddy|accessdate=22 October 2016}} ==Political activity== Lynn was a member of the executive committee of the [[Dublin Women's Suffrage Association|Irish Women's Suffragette and Local Government Association]] (IWSLGA) from 1903, and remained on the executive until 1916.{{cite book|last1=Ó hÓgartaigh|first1=Margaret|title=Kathleen Lynn: Irishwoman, Patriot, Doctor|date=2006|publisher=Irish Academic Press|location=Dublin}} Lynn was a member of the radical British Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU) from 1908 and she was also said to be on friendly terms with the suffragist Sylvia Pankhurst.{{cite book|last1=Ó hOgartaigh|first1=Margaret|title=Kathleen Lynn: Irishwoman, Patriot, Doctor|date=2006|publisher=Irish Academic Press|location=Dublin, Ireland}} She was part of a mass meeting in 1912, demanding that women's suffrage be included in the [[Government of Ireland Act 1914|Third Home Rule Bill]] of that year. Lynn supported the workers during the [[Dublin lock-out|1913 lock-out]] and worked with [[Constance Markievicz]] and others in the soup kitchens in Liberty Hall, becoming close to Markievicz and James Connolly.{{cite web|last1=Stokes|first1=Tom|title=Kathleen Lynn|url=https://theirishrepublic.wordpress.com/tag/kathleen-lynn/|website=The Irish Republic|accessdate=23 November 2016}} In 1913, at Markievicz's request, she treated [[Helena Molony]]. Molony, who was active in a number of political movements, stayed with Lynn in her Rathmines home following an illness. As a result of the influence of Molony and Markievicz, Lynn became an active participant in the suffragist, labour and nationalist movements. "We used to have long talks and she converted me to the National Movement," Lynn wrote.{{cite news|last1=Wheelock|title=1916: Diary of rebel doctor Kathleen Lynn|publisher=The Irish Times}} She joined the [[Irish Citizen Army]] and was chief medical officer during the [[Easter Rising|1916 Easter Rising]]. She described herself as "a Red Cross doctor and a belligerent" when she was arrested.[https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/03/16/opinion/eight-women-of-irelands-1916-easter-rising.html Eight Women of the Easter Rising] The New York Times, March 16, 2016 For her part in the Rising, Lynn was imprisoned in [[Kilmainham Gaol]] with her comrades Markievicz, Molony and [[Madeleine ffrench-Mullen]]. Lynn remained active in the Nationalist movement; she was elected vice-president of the Sinn Féin executive in 1917{{cite news|last1=Wheelock|title=1916: Diary of rebel doctor Kathleen Lynn|publisher=The Irish Times}} and in 1923, Lynn was elected to [[Dáil Éireann]] as a Sinn Féin [[Teachta Dála]] (TD) for the [[Dublin County (Dáil constituency)|Dublin County constituency]] at the [[Irish general election, 1923|1923 general election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oireachtas.ie/members-hist/default.asp?housetype=0&HouseNum=4&MemberID=659&ConstID=77|title=Kathleen Florence Lynn|work=Oireachtas Members Database|accessdate=26 April 2009}} In accordance with Sinn Féin [[Abstentionism|abstentionist]] policy of the time, she did not take her seat in Dáil Éireann. She lost her seat in the [[Irish general election, June 1927|June 1927 general election]].{{cite web|url=http://electionsireland.org/candidate.cfm?ID=1229|title=Kathleen Lynn|work=ElectionsIreland.org|accessdate=26 April 2009}} She unsuccessfully contested the [[Dublin County by-election, 1927|August 1927 by-election]] for Dublin County. Lynn claimed, many years after the 1916 rising, that it was suffrage that converted her to republicanism, saying: "I saw that people got the wrong impression about suffrage and that led me to examine the Irish question."{{cite book|last1=Ó hOgartaigh|first1=Margaret|title=kathleen Lynn: Irishwoman, Patriot, Doctor|date=2006|publisher=Irish Academic Press|location=Dublin, Ireland}} She was given a gold fibula bone-shaped brooch as a token of gratitude from the Irish Citizen Army for her help in the medical preparation for the Rising. Lynn eventually left politics in 1927, increasingly frustrated by Sinn Féin's refusal to embrace social reform and health care.{{cite web |url=http://thewildgeese.irish/profiles/blogs/dr-kathleen-lynn-1874-1955-rebel-chief-of-medial-officer-during |title=Dr. Kathleen Lynn -- Irish Rebel, Politician and Humanitarian |date=1 August 2016 |publisher=The Wild Geese| accessdate=23 October 2017}} ==Medical career== Lynn decided to become a doctor when she was 16. She was one of the first female medical graduates from [[University College Dublin]]. Lynn became politically active and worked in Liberty Hall providing food and care for the poor and destitute families during the turbulent time of the 1913 Dublin Lock-Out.{{cite web |title=Lynn, Kathleen (1874-1955), A revolutionary doctor |url=http://www.ucd.ie/medicine/ourcommunity/ouralumni/alumniprofilesinterviews/drkathleenlynn/ |website=www.ucd.ie |publisher=UCD |accessdate=13 October 2016}} Lynn's medical career was defined by her work at [[Saint Ultan's Children's Hospital]], which she established in Dublin in 1919, with a group of female activists. Lynn's work with Dublin's inner-city poor had convinced her of the need for a hospital to provide medical and educational facilities for impoverished mothers and infants. Earlier in her career, Lynn had experienced discrimination in applying for hospital positions due to her gender, and Saint Ultan's was the only hospital in Ireland entirely managed by women.Ó hÓgartaigh, Margaret, ''Kathleen Lynn. Irishwoman, Patriot, Doctor''. (Irish Academic Press, 2006). pp. 68–69. Saint Ultan's Hospital grew rapidly, and from 1937 became the centre for [[Bacillus Calmette-Guérin|BCG]] vaccination in Ireland. The hospital closed in 1983. [[File:Grave of Kathleen Lynn1 (1874-1955), Deansgrange cemetery, Co. Dublin.jpg|thumb|Grave of Kathleen Lynn (1874-1955), Deansgrange cemetery, Co. Dublin.]] Lynn was the chief medical officer for the [[Irish Citizen Army]]. At the request of rebel leader [[James Connolly]] she joined the Irish Citzien's Army during the 1916 rising and was appointed as Captain and Chief Medical Officer. She provided medical training to members of the ICA also taught the [[Cumann na mBan]].{{cite web|title=Lynn, Kathleen (1874-1955), 1916: Diary of rebel doctor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/health-family/1916-diary-of-rebel-doctor-kathleen-lynn-1.2583254|website=www.irishtimes.com|publisher=Harriet Wheelock|accessdate=13 October 2016}} Dr. Lynn (along with writer Sean O'Casey) advocated the use of the Irish language in [[Church of Ireland]] liturgy and many events for St. Ultans were advertised in the Irish language.[http://www.historyireland.com/20th-century-contemporary-history/st-ultans-a-womens-hospital-for-infants/ St Ultans a Womens Hospital for Infants] www.historyireland.com ==Death and legacy== Lynn died in 1955 and was buried [[Military funeral|with full military honours]] in recognition of her role in the Rising and the [[War of Independence]]. She was so well known that crowds in Dublin lined the streets to show their respects. After Lynn's death, [[Éamon de Valera]] set up the Kathleen Lynn Memorial Committee, which lasted for eight straight years and resulted in the opening of a surgical unit at [[St. Ultan's Hospital]] in 1964, which eventually shut in 1975 due to funding difficulties. Four diaries recorded by Lynn between 1916 and 1955 were transcribed over two years by librarian Margaret Connolly. The detailed diaries chronicle her medical, political and social life and are held at the Royal College of Physicians in Ireland archive. They provided source material for the 2010 documentary entitled ‘Kathleen Lynn – An Dochtúir Reabhlóideach’ by Loop Line Film and director Sé Merry Doyle.{{cite web|title=Kathleen Lynn - The Rebel Doctor|url=http://loopline.com/kathleenlynn/|website=loopline.com|accessdate=11 November 2016}} Historian [[Margaret Ó hÓgartaigh]] wrote her biography, ''Kathleen Lynn, Irishwoman, Patriot, Doctor'' (Irish Academic Press, 2006).[https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/people/distinguished-and-prolific-historian-of-women-of-ireland-1.2063000 The Irish Times Obituary of Margaret Ó hÓgartaigh, "Distinguished and prolific historian of women of Ireland"] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== * {{cite book|last=Ó hÓgartaigh|first= Margaret|title=Kathleen Lynn|journal=Dictionary of Irish Biography|publisher=Cambridge University Press|date=2010}} * {{cite book|last=Ó hÓgartaigh|first=Margaret|title=Kathleen Lynn: Irishwoman, Patriot, Doctor|publisher=Irish Academic Press|date=2006}} {{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{s-bef|before = [[Arthur Griffith]] and [[Michael O'Flanagan]]}} {{s-ttl|title = [[Leader of Sinn Féin#Vice-Presidents|Vice-President of Sinn Féin]]
{{small|with [[P. J. Ruttledge]] (1923–1926)}} |years = 1923–1927}} {{s-aft|after = [[Mary MacSwiney]] and [[John Madden (Irish politician)|John Madden]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lynn, Kathleen}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1955 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Irish people]] [[Category:19th-century Irish people]] [[Category:Irish Anglicans]] [[Category:Alumni of the Royal University of Ireland]] [[Category:Burials at Deans Grange Cemetery]] [[Category:Women Teachtaí Dála]] [[Category:Irish military doctors]] [[Category:Early Sinn Féin TDs]] [[Category:Protestant Irish nationalists]] [[Category:Members of the 4th Dáil]] [[Category:People from County Mayo]] [[Category:People from County Galway]] [[Category:Politicians from County Dublin]] [[Category:Irish women medical doctors]] [[Category:Women in war in Ireland]] [[Category:People of the Easter Rising]] [[Category:20th-century women politicians]] [[Category:Irish Citizen Army members]] [[Category:Irish pediatricians]]

revision.text:
'''Keith Lofstrom''' is an American [[electrical engineer]]. He has a BSEE and MSEE from [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref>{{Citation | last = Lofstrom | first = Keith | title = Sinusoidal supply Josephson logic | journal = U.C. Berkeley masters thesis | year = 1975 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=2WQMGwAACAAJ&dq=sinusoidal.supply.josephson.logic&hl=en&ei=YtYsTqKBGe_4mAWFi_25Dw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA }} </ref> He is more widely known in the [[space advocacy]] community for a ground-based space launcher design, the [[Launch loop|Launch Loop]],<ref>{{cite journal | last = Lofstrom | first = Keith H. | title = The launch loop -- a low cost Earth-to-high orbit launch system - Paper 85-1368 | publisher = 21st AIAA, SAE, ASME, and ASEE, Joint Propulsion Conference | location = Monterey, CA | date = 8–10 July 1985 | url = http://launchloop.com/LaunchLoop?action=AttachFile&do=get&target=launchloop.pdf | format = PDF }} </ref><ref>{{cite news | first = Charles | last = Radley | title = Local inventor says launch loop would greatly reduce cost of space travel | publisher = [[Examiner.com]] | work = Gadgets and Tech: Portland Science Examiner | location = San Francisco | date=September 14, 2009 }} </ref><ref>{{Cite encyclopedia | title = Space Towers | last = [[:ru:Болонкин, Александр Александрович|Alexander Bolonkin]]
| chapter = 8 | editor1-first = Viorel | editor1-last = Badescu | editor2-first = Richard Brook | editor2-last = Cathcart | editor3-first = Roelof D. | editor3-last = Schuiling | encyclopedia = Macro-engineering: a challenge for the future | pages = 146–7 | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | year = 2006 | isbn = 1-4020-3739-2 }} </ref> for which he has been credited by name in several works of science fiction.<ref>{{cite journal | journal = [[Amazing Science-Fiction]] | last = Pohl | first = Frederik | authorlink = Frederik Pohl | title = Gateway III — Beyond the Gate (Part 1 of 3) | page = 80 | publisher = Ultimate Pub. Co | year = 1983 | volume = 57 }} </ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Pohl | first = Frederik | authorlink = Frederik Pohl | title = [[Heechee Rendezvous]] | page = 91 | publisher = [[Ballantine Books]] | year = 1983 | volume = 3 | work = Heechee Saga | isbn = 0-345-30062-9 }} </ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Clarke | first1 = Arthur C. | authorlink1 = Arthur C. Clarke | last2 = Pohl | first2 = Frederik | authorlink2 = Frederik Pohl | title = [[The Last Theorem]] |date=February 2009 | page = 55 | publisher = [[HarperCollins|HarperVoyager]] | location = London | isbn = 978-0-00-729002-4 }} </ref><ref>{{Cite book | last = Forward | first = Robert L. | authorlink = Robert L. Forward | title = [[Starquake (novel)|Starquake]] | year = 1985 | page = v | publisher = [[Ballantine Books|Ballantine]] | location = London | isbn = 978-0-345-28349-8 }} </ref> [[Frederik Pohl]], who used the idea in several of his stories, once wrote that, of all the [[non-rocket spacelaunch]] concepts, he liked the Lofstrom Loop "best of all."<ref>{{cite journal | journal = [[Amazing Science-Fiction]] | title = Interview with Frederik Pohl | page = 98 | publisher = Ultimate Pub. Co | year = 1995 | volume = 69 | issue = 590 | url = https://books.google.com/books?ei=Dw8tTr6NO66imQXUhP25Dw&ct=result&id=UG0sAQAAIAAJ&dq=lofstrom+loop&q=best.of.all#search_anchor }} </ref>
As an electrical engineer, Lofstrom specializes in [[mixed-signal integrated circuit]] design. A paper he wrote on [[boundary scan]] methods was one of two to receive an Honorable Mention at the 1997 [[IEEE]] International Test Conference.<ref>{{cite book | title = IEEE International Test Conference Proceedings | page = 8 | year = 1997 | isbn = 0-7803-4210-0 }} [https://books.google.com/books?ei=UtksTpntHcWemQWx2v25Dw&ct=result&id=z0JGAQAAIAAJ&dq=best.paper+%22Early+Capture+for+Boundary+Scan+Timing+Measurements.%22&q=%22Early+Capture+for+Boundary+Scan+Timing+Measurements.%22#search_anchor] </ref> One of his 9 patents is for a way to read an individual digital ID for [[integrated circuits]] that arises from random atomic variations inherent in the [[semiconductor device fabrication]] process.<ref>{{Citation | inventor-last = Lofstrom | inventor-first = Keith | inventorlink = Keith Lofstrom | publication-date = Dec 12, 2000 | issue-date = Dec 12, 2000 | title = System for providing an integrated circuit with a unique identification | country-code = US | description = | patent-number = 6161213 }} </ref><ref>{{cite web | title = A unique, repeatable, individual digital ID | url = http://www.siidtech.com/index.html | date = Nov 30, 2007 | accessdate = 2011-07-24 }} </ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Lofstrom | first1 = K. | last2 = Daasch | first2 = W. | last3 = Taylor | first3 = D. | title = IC Identification Circuit using Device Mismatch | journal = 2000 IEEE International Solid-State Circuits Conference Digest of Technical Papers | id = IEEE Cat. No. OOCH37056 | volume = 43 | url = http://www.siidtech.com/isscc2K.pdf | accessdate = 2011-07-24 }} </ref>
One of his more recent efforts in speculative space systems is Server Sky, a very large [[satellite constellation]] in Earth orbit using [[thin-film solar cells]] to power [[data center]] computers integrated into the same [[Wafer (electronics)|wafers]] as the PV cells.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Lofstrom | first = Keith | authorlink = Keith Lofstrom | journal = Online Journal of Space Communication | title = Server Sky - Data Centers in Orbit | issue = 16 | date = Winter 2010 | url = http://spacejournal.ohio.edu/issue16/lofstrom.html }} </ref>
== See also ==
* [[Lofstrom loop]]
== References ==
<references/>
== External links == * [http://www.keithl.com/ Personal website] * [http://www.kl-ic.com/index.html KLIC] - IC design consultancy
{{DEFAULTSORT:Lofstrom, Keith}} [[Category:Space advocates]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley College of Engineering alumni]] [[Category:American inventors]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Lists of Marvel Comics to [[:Category:Marvel Comics-related lists]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 18]].
revision.text:
[[Marvel Comics]] Editor-in-Chief [[Stan Lee]] was known for bestowing humorous nicknames on himself, as well as Marvel's other creators, members of the "Bullpen," and various staff members (i.e.., "Marveldom Assembled"). Later editors-in-chief like [[Roy Thomas]] and [[Archie Goodwin (comics)|Archie Goodwin]] continued the tradition, until [[Jim Shooter]] discontinued the practice in the 1980s. It was re-established by [[Mark Gruenwald]] when he started editing "[[Bullpen Bulletins]]" in the late 1980s. The convention was inspired, at least in part, by a [[Classical Hollywood cinema|Hollywood]] tradition, where [[character actor]]s in particular were given colorful nicknames to aid in their name recognition.[http://www.wtv-zone.com/silverager/interviews/esposito_2.shtml Mike Esposito interview, The Silver Age Sage (2008).] Accessed Feb. 13, 2009. Monikers like Stan "The Man" Lee and Jack "King" Kirby permeated into mass culture. This is a list of those nicknames. {{compact ToC|refs=no|extlinks=no|center=yes}} {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! Name !! Area !! page.title: List of people from American Samoa

revision.comment: Added pipe to category
revision.text:
This is a list of '''[[WP:N|notable]] people from [[American Samoa]]'''.
==Beauty pageants== *[[Marion Malena]] is a multiple beauty pageant winner and performer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seattletimes.com/html/photogalleries/localnews2021303102/9.html?news=/html/photogalleries/photography2022293604 |title=Seattle Pride Parade |publisher=The Seattle Times |date=2013-06-30 |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref> Malena resides in [[Seattle]], Wa.
==Film and stage== *[[John Kneubuhl]] was a Hollywood screenwriter, playwright and [[Polynesia]]n historian. He wrote for American television series such as ''[[The Fugitive (TV series)|The Fugitive]]'', ''[[Gunsmoke]]'', ''[[The Wild Wild West]]'', ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'', ''[[The Invaders]]'' and ''[[Hawaii Five-O (1968 TV series)|Hawaii Five-O]]''. An annual award named in his honor is presented by the department of education to local students. *[[Freddie Letuli]] was the pioneer of the world-famous Polynesian fire knife dance. He toured across the United States and Europe, appearing in TV shows and movies. Letuli died in 2003. The annual World Fire Knife competition is held each year in his honor. *[[Al Harrington (actor)|Al Harrington]] is a Hollywood character actor best known for playing Detective Ben Kokua on the original ''[[Hawaii Five-O (1968 TV series)|Hawaii Five-O]]''. *Hollywood actor [[Eric Stoltz]] lived with his family in American Samoa. His father was the principal of Leone High School in the late 1960s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://susanrstoltz.com/samoa/ |title=Samoa |publisher=Susan R. Stoltz |date= |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref> *[[Gary Scott Thompson]] is a Hollywood screenwriter, television producer and director. He is best known for his work on the ''[[Fast & the Furious]]'' film series. *[[Setu Taase]] is a film actor. He is best known for playing Junior Palaita in ''[[Gridiron Gang]]''.
*[[Queen Muhammad Ali]] (Queen Melé Le'iato Tuiasosopo Muhammad Ali) is an award-winning film director,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.statepress.com/article/2016/02/bars4justice-documentary-showing|title=Black African Coalition brings award-winning documentary, #Bars4Justice, to ASU|website=www.statepress.com|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=Ali|first=Queen Muhammad|title=#bars4Justice|date=2015-10-01|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt5091710/|last2=Khaaliq|first2=Hakeem|accessdate=2016-03-07}}</ref> photographer, graphic design artist, multimedia activist, [[lecturer]], television producer,<ref>{{Citation|title=¿Quiénes son los afro-mexicanos?|date=2014-07-14|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3885648/combined|accessdate=2016-03-07}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=T.I.'s Road to Redemption|date=2009-02-10|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1374681/combined|accessdate=2016-03-07}}</ref> model, writer, [[visual anthropologist]] and the CEO of [[Nation19]] Magazine.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://azinformant.com/african-diaspora-authority-dr-runoko-rashidi-lectures-in-arizona-for-first-time/|title=African Diaspora Authority Dr. Runoko Rashidi Lectures In Arizona For First Time|website=azinformant.com|access-date=2016-03-07}}</ref> Ali is also the great-granddaughter of [[Paramount Chief Tuli Le’iato|Paramount Chief Tuli Le'iato]] of [[American Samoa]].
==Literature==
*Author [[Sia Figiel]] was an educator for Fa'asao-Marist and Samoana High School. Figiel was a special liaison for the congressman's office for several years. *[[Fofó Iosefa Fiti Sunia]] founded American Samoa's first newspaper in the 1960s and was later elected as a non-voting delegate to the U.S. House of Representatives, serving from 1981 to 1988. Sunia published a series of books, among them ''The story of the legislature of American Samoa: 1948–1998'' and ''Puputoa: A Host of Heroes''.{{cn|date=March 2017}}
==Music==
*[[The Katinas]] is a famed contemporary Christian music group composed of brothers.
==Politics==
*[[Tulsi Gabbard]] is a member of the United States congress representing Hawaii's 2nd congressional district.
*[[Aumua Amata Coleman Radewagen]] is a member of the United States House of Representatives representing American Samoa. Her father was the first democratically elected governor of American Samoa. Coleman Radewagen is a Republican, and she serves on the Committee on Natural Resources, the Committee on small business and the Committee on Veterans' Affairs.
==Sports==
*[[Tony Solaita]] was Samoa's only [[major league baseball]] player. He played for the [[New York Yankees]], [[Kansas City Royals]], [[California Angels]], [[Montreal Expos]] and [[Toronto Blue Jays]]. Solaita was killed during a family dispute in 1990. A popular park and sporting field in [[Tafuna]] is named in his honor.
*[[Afa Anoaʻi]] and [[Sika Anoaʻi]] are professional wrestlers known as [[The Wild Samoans]]. They held 21 tag team championships around the world. They are the patriarchs of the [[Anoaʻi family]], which includes many professional wrestlers, including [[Yokozuna (wrestler)|Yokozuna]], former tag team champions [[Rikishi (wrestler)|Solofa Fatu]], [[Sam Fatu]] and [[Samula Anoaʻi]], [[Roman Reigns]] and [[Umaga (wrestler)|Eddie Fatu]] (Umaga), among others.
*The High Chief [[Peter Maivia]], a blood brother to the Anoaʻi family, was also a professional wrestler, promoting a [[National Wrestling Alliance]] territory out of Hawaii and becoming a folk hero among the Samoan population of San Francisco. He is the grandfather of [[Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson]], who inducted him into the [[WWE Hall of Fame]] in 2008.
*[[Jack Thompson (American football)|Jack Thompson]], "The Throwin' Samoan", was a backup quarterback for the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] and the first Samoan member of a team that made it to the NFL Super Bowl, in [[Super Bowl XVI|1982]], although Thompson did not play in that game.
* [[San Francisco 49ers]] nose tackle [[Manu Tuiasosopo]] was the first Samoan to play in a Super Bowl, in 1985.
*[[Cocoa Samoa]] was a professional wrestler in the 1980s. He held several championship titles.
*[[Jonathan Fanene]] became the first NFL player to be appointed to a cabinet position in the American Samoa government in 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cincyjungle.com/veteransofcincinnati/2014/1/17/5317340/former-bengal-jonathan-fanene-appointed-Somoa-cabinet |title=Former Bengal Jonathan Fanene is appointed to the American Samoa cabinet |publisher=Cincy Jungle |date= |accessdate=2014-02-26}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
